data.md: He has matted locks and two tongues. His face has the colour of copper, and he is clad in a lion's skin. That irresistible god assumes such a dreadful form.

data.v: असिर्गदा धनुः शक्तिस्त्रिशूलं मुद्गरः शरः । मुसलं परशुश्चक्रं प्रासो दण्डर्ष्टितोमराः ॥
सर्वप्रहरणीयानि सन्ति यानीह कानिचित् । दण्ड एव हि सर्वात्मा लोके चरति मूर्तिमान् ॥
data.md: Assuming again the form of the sword, the bow, the mace, the dart, the trident, the mallet, the arrow, the thick and short club, the battleaxe, the discus, the noose, the heavy bludgeon, the rapier, the lance, and, in fact, of every sort of weapon that exist on Earth, Punishment moves in the world.

data.v: भिन्दंश्छिन्दन्रुजन्कृन्तन्दारयन्पाटयंस्तथा । घातयन्नभिधावंश्च दण्ड एव चरत्युत ॥
data.md: Indeed, Punishment moves on Earth, piercing and cutting and assenting and looping off and dividing and striking and killing and rushing against its victims.

data.v: असिर्विशसनो धर्मस्तीक्ष्णवर्त्मा दुरासदः । श्रीगर्भो विजयः शास्ता व्यवहारः प्रजागरः ॥
शास्त्रं ब्राह्मणमन्त्रश्च शास्ता प्राग्वचनं गतः । धर्मपालोऽक्षरो देवः सत्यगो नित्यगो ग्रहः ॥
असङ्गो रुद्रतनयो मनुज्येष्ठः शिवंकरः । नामान्येतानि दण्डस्य कीर्तितानि युधिष्ठिर ॥
दण्डो हि भगवान्विष्णुर्यज्ञो नारायणः प्रभुः । शश्वद्रूपं महद्बिभ्रन्महापुरुष उच्यते ॥
data.md: Punishment is the holy Vishnu. He is the powerful Narayana. And because he always puts on dreadful from, therefore he is called Mahapurusha.

data.v: यथोक्ता ब्रह्मकन्येति लक्ष्मीर्नीतिः सरस्वती । दण्डनीतिर्जगद्धात्री दण्डो हि बहुविग्रहः ॥
data.md: His wife Morality passes by the names of Brahman's daughter, Lakshmi, Vritti, Sarasvati, and Mother of the universe. Punishment has thus many forms.

data.v: अर्थानर्थौ सुखं दुःखं धर्माधर्मौ बलाबले । दौर्भाग्यं भागधेयं च पुण्यापुण्ये गुणागुणौ ॥
कामाकामावृतुर्मासः शर्वरी दिवसः क्षणः । अप्रसादः प्रसादश्च हर्षः क्रोधः शमो दमः ॥
दैवं पुरुषकारश्च मोक्षामोक्षौ भयाभये । हिंसाहिंसे तपो यज्ञः संयमोऽथ विषाविषम् ॥
अन्तश्चादिश्च मध्यं च कृत्यानां च प्रपञ्चनम् । मदः प्रमादो दर्पश्च दम्भो धैर्यं नयानयौ ॥
अशक्तिः शक्तिरित्येव मानस्तम्भौ व्ययाव्ययौ । विनयश्च विसर्गश्च कालाकालौ च भारत ॥
अनृतं ज्ञाज्ञता सत्यं श्रद्धाश्रद्धे तथैव च । क्लीबता व्यवसायश्च लाभालाभौ जयाजयौ ॥
तीक्ष्णता मृदुता मृत्युरागमानागमौ तथा । विराद्धिश्चैव राद्धिश्च कार्याकार्ये बलाबले ॥
असूया चानसूया च धर्माधर्मौ तथैव च । अपत्रपानपत्रपे ह्रीश्च संपद्विपच्च ह ॥
तेजः कर्मणि पाण्डित्यं वाक्शक्तिस्तत्त्वबुद्धिता । एवं दण्डस्य कौरव्य लोकेऽस्मिन्बहुरूपता ॥
न स्याद्यदीह दण्डो वै प्रमथेयुः परस्परम् । भयाद्दण्डस्य चान्योन्यं घ्नन्ति नैव युधिष्ठिर ॥
data.md: If punishment had not existed, all creatures would have struck one another. Through fear of punishment, O Yudhishthira, living creatures do not kill one another.

data.v: दण्डेन रक्ष्यमाणा हि राजन्नहरहः प्रजाः । राजानं वर्धयन्तीह तस्माद्दण्डः परायणम् ॥
data.md: O king, always protected by punishment, the subjects, increase the might of their ruler. It is for this that punishment is regarded as the highest refuge of all.

data.v: व्यवस्थापयति क्षिप्रमिमं लोकं नरेश्वर । सत्ये व्यवस्थितो धर्मो ब्राह्मणेष्ववतिष्ठते ॥
data.md: Punishment, o king, quickly sets the world on the path of righteousness. Depend upon truth, righteousness exits in Brahmanas.

data.v: धर्मयुक्ता द्विजाः श्रेष्ठा वेदयुक्ता भवन्ति च । बभूव यज्ञो वेदेभ्यो यज्ञः प्रीणाति देवताः ॥
data.md: Filled with righteousness, leading Brahmanas take to the study of the Vedas. From the Vedas the sacrifices originate. Sacrifices please the gods.

data.v: प्रीताश्च देवता नित्यमिन्द्रे परिददत्युत । अन्नं ददाति शक्रश्चाप्यनुगृह्णन्निमाः प्रजाः ॥
data.md: The gods being gratified, commend the dwellers of the Earth to Indra. For benefiting the inhabitants of the Earth, Indra gives them food.

data.v: प्राणाश्च सर्वभूतानां नित्यमन्ने प्रतिष्ठिताः । तस्मात्प्रजाः प्रतिष्ठन्ते दण्डो जागर्ति तासु च ॥
data.md: The life of all creatures depends upon food. From food creatures derive their support and growth. Punishment in the shape of king remains wakeful amongst them.

data.v: एवंप्रयोजनश्चैव दण्डः क्षत्रियतां गतः । रक्षन्प्रजाः प्रजागर्ति नित्यं सुविहितोऽक्षरः ॥
data.md: For serving this object, punishment assumes the form of a Kshatriya among men. Protecting men he remains awake, always careful and never decaying.

data.v: ईश्वरः पुरुषः प्राणः सत्त्वं वित्तं प्रजापतिः । भूतात्मा जीव इत्येव नामभिः प्रोच्यतेऽष्टभिः ॥
data.md: Punishment has again these other eight names, viz., God, Men, Life, Power, Heart, the Lord of all creatures, the Soul of all things, and the Living creature.

data.v: अददद्दण्ड एवास्मै ध्रुवमैश्वर्यमेव च । बले नयश्च संयुक्तः सदा पञ्चविधात्मकः ॥
data.md: God gave both prosperity and the rod of punishment to the king who is possessed of strength and who is a combination of five expedients.

data.v: कुलबाहुधनामात्याः प्रज्ञा चोक्ता बलानि च । आहार्यं चाष्टकैर्द्रव्यैर्बलमन्यद्युधिष्ठिर ॥
data.md: Nobility of blood, rich ministers, knowledge, the various kinds of forces with the eight objects mentioned below, and the other forces, should be sought for by the king, o Yudhishthira.

data.v: हस्तिनोऽश्वा रथाः पत्तिर्नावो विष्टिस्तथैव च । दैशिकाश्चारकाश्चैव तदष्टाङ्गं बलं स्मृतम् ॥
data.md: a Those eight objects are elephants, horses, cars, infantry, boats, impressed labourers, increase of population, and cattle such as sheep, etc.

data.v: अष्टाङ्गस्य तु युक्तस्य हस्तिनो हस्तियायिनः । अश्वारोहाः पदाताश्च मन्त्रिणो रसदाश्च ये ॥
data.md: Well-armed soldiers car-warriors, elephantwarriors, cavalry, infantry officers and surgeons form the limbs.

data.v: भिक्षुकाः प्राड्विवाकाश्च मौहूर्ता दैवचिन्तकाः । कोशो मित्राणि धान्यं च सर्वोपकरणानि च ॥
data.md: Beggars, principal judges, judges, astrologers, performers of propitiatory and Atharvan rites, treasury, allies, grain, and all other requisites, form the body, composed of seven attributes and eight limbs, of a kingdom. Punishment is another powerful limb of kingdom. Punishment is the creator of a kingdom.

data.v: सप्तप्रकृति चाष्टाङ्गं शरीरमिह यद्विदुः । राज्यस्य दण्ड एवाङ्गं दण्डः प्रभव एव च ॥
data.md: Beggars, principal judges, judges, astrologers, performers of propitiatory and Atharvan rites, treasury, allies, grain, and all other requisites, form the body, composed of seven attributes and eight limbs, of a kingdom. Punishment is another powerful limb of kingdom. Punishment is the creator of a kingdom.

data.v: ईश्वरेण प्रयत्नेन धारणे क्षत्रियस्य हि । दण्डो दत्तः समानात्मा दण्डो हीदं सनातनम् । राज्ञां पूज्यतमो नान्यो यथाधर्मप्रदर्शनः ॥
data.md: God himself has, with great care, sent Punishment for the use of the Kshatriya. This eternal universe is impartial Punishment's self.

data.v: ब्रह्मणा लोकरक्षार्थं स्वधर्मस्थापनाय च । भर्तृप्रत्यय उत्पन्नो व्यवहारस्तथापरः । तस्माद्यः सहितो दृष्टो भर्तृप्रत्ययलक्षणः ॥
data.md: There is another kind of Vyavahara (Law) originating from the disputes of litigants which also has sprung from Brahman. Principally marked by a belief in either of the two parties, that Vyavahara, (Law) yields great good.

data.v: व्यवहारस्तु वेदात्मा वेदप्रत्यय उच्यते । मौलश्च नरशार्दूल शास्त्रोक्तश्च तथापरः ॥
data.md: There is another kind of Vyavahara which has the Veda for its soul. It also originates from the Veda. There is, O foremost of kings, a third kind of Vyavahara (Law) which is connected with family customs but which is quite of a piece with the scriptures.

data.v: उक्तो यश्चापि दण्डोऽसौ भर्तृप्रत्ययलक्षणः । ज्ञेयो न स नरेन्द्रस्थो दण्डप्रत्यय एव च ॥
data.md: That Vyavahara (Law) which has, as above, been said to be marked by a belief in either of two litigant parties, should be known by us as being inherent in the king. It should be also known by the name of Punishment, as also by the name of Evidence.

data.v: दण्डप्रत्ययदृष्टोऽपि व्यवहारात्मकः स्मृतः । व्यवहारः स्मृतो यश्च स वेदविषयात्मकः ॥
data.md: Although Punishment is regulated by Evidence, yet it depends upon Law. Vyavahara (law) is really based upon Vedic precepts.

data.v: यश्च वेदप्रसूतात्मा स धर्मो गुणदर्शकः । धर्मप्रत्यय उत्पन्नो यथाधर्मः कृतात्मभिः ॥
data.md: That Vyavahara (Law), which originates from the Vedas, is Morality or duty. It yields good to persons believing in duty and morality; men of purified souls have spoken of that Vyavahara (Law) as they have done of ordinary law.

data.v: व्यवहारः प्रजागोप्ता ब्रह्मदिष्टो युधिष्ठिर । त्रीन्धारयति लोकान्वै सत्यात्मा भूतिवर्धनः ॥
data.md: The third kind of Vyavahara is also a protector of men, and it also originates from the Veda, O Yudhishthira! It keeps up the three worlds. It has Truth for its soul and yields prosperity.

data.v: यश्च दण्डः स दृष्टो नो व्यवहारः सनातनः । व्यवहारश्च यो दृष्टः स धर्म इति नः श्रुतः । यश्च वेदः स वै धर्मो यश्च धर्मः स सत्पथः ॥
data.md: That which is punishment is eternal Vyavahara. That which has been said to be Vyavahara is really the Veda.

data.v: ब्रह्मा प्रजापतिः पूर्वं बभूवाथ पितामहः । लोकानां स हि सर्वेषां ससुरासुररक्षसाम् । समनुष्योरगवतां कर्ता चैव स भूतकृत् ॥
data.md: Brahman is the Creator of the entire universe with the gods and Asuras and Rakshasas and human beings and snakes, and of every other things.

data.v: ततो नो व्यवहारोऽयं भर्तृप्रत्ययलक्षणः । तस्मादिदमवोचाम व्यवहारनिदर्शनम् ॥
data.md: Hence that law which is characterised by a belief in either of two litigant parties has also originated from him. Therefore, he has laid down the following regarding Vyavahara.

data.v: माता पिता च भ्राता च भार्या चाथ पुरोहितः । नादण्ड्यो विद्यते राज्ञां यः स्वधर्मे न तिष्ठति ॥
data.md: Neither mother, nor father, nor brother, nor wife, nor priest, is unpunishable with that king who governs agreeable to his duty.'

data.v: अत्राप्युदाहरन्तीममितिहासं पुरातनम् । अङ्गेषु राजा द्युतिमान्वसुहोम इति श्रुतः ॥
data.md: Bhishma said “Regarding it is cited the following old story. There was among the Angas a highly effulgent king called Vasuhoma.

data.v: स राजा धर्मनित्यः सन्सह पत्न्या महातपाः । मुञ्जपृष्ठं जगामाथ देवर्षिगणपूजितम् ॥
data.md: That king was always engaged in acts of piety, and accompanied by his wife he always practised the austerest penances. He went to the spot called Munjaprishtha highly respected by the Pitris and the celestial Rishis.

data.v: तत्र शृङ्गे हिमवतो मेरौ कनकपर्वते । यत्र मुञ्जवटे रामो जटाहरणमादिशत् ॥
data.md: There, on that peak of Himavat, near the golden mountain of Meru. Rama, sitting under the shade of a well-known banian, had tied his matted locks together.

data.v: तदाप्रभृति राजेन्द्र ऋषिभिः संशितव्रतैः । मुञ्जपृष्ठ इति प्रोक्तः स देशो रुद्रसेवितः ॥
data.md: From that time, O king, the spot, which is a favourite resort of Rudra, passed by the naine of Munjaprishtha among Rishis of rigid vows.

data.v: स तत्र बहुभिर्युक्तः सदा श्रुतिमयैर्गुणैः । ब्राह्मणानामनुमतो देवर्षिसदृशोऽभवत् ॥
data.md: Living there, king Vasuhoma acquired many pious attributes and, having gained the regard of the Brahmanas, came to be regarded as a celestial Rishi in holiness.

data.v: तं कदाचिददीनात्मा सखा शक्रस्य मानितः । अभ्यागच्छन्महीपालो मान्धाता शत्रुकर्शनः ॥
data.md: One day, that grinder of enemies, that friend of Shakra, viz., king Mandhata of great soul, came to Vasuhoma on his mountain retreat.

data.v: सोऽभिसृत्य तु मान्धाता वसुहोमं नराधिपम् । दृष्ट्वा प्रकृष्टं तपसा विनयेनाभ्यतिष्ठत ॥
data.md: Arrived there, and seeing king Vasuhoma of austere penances, stood humbly before the latter.

data.v: वसुहोमोऽपि राज्ञो वै गामर्घ्यं च न्यवेदयत् । अष्टाङ्गस्य च राज्यस्य पप्रच्छ कुशलं तदा ॥
data.md: Vasuhoma offered his guest water to wash his feet, and the Arghya consisting of the usual articles, and enquired of him about the wellbeing or otherwise of his kingdom consisting of seven limbs.

data.v: सद्भिराचरितं पूर्वं यथावदनुयायिनम् । अपृच्छद्वसुहोमस्तं राजन्किं करवाणि ते ॥
data.md: After this, Vasuhoma addressed his royal guest who strictly followed the conduct of the righteous men of old, saying,-What, О king, shall I do for you.

data.v: सोऽब्रवीत्परमप्रीतो मान्धाता राजसत्तमम् । वसुहोमं महाप्राज्ञमासीनं कुरुनन्दन ॥
data.md: Thus addressed, O delighter of the Kurus, Mandhatri, that best of kings, highly pleased, answered the greatly wise Vasuhoma seated at his ease, in the following words.

data.v: बृहस्पतेर्मतं राजन्नधीतं सकलं त्वया । तथैवौशनसं शास्त्रं विज्ञातं ते नराधिप ॥
data.md: Mandhatri said You have, O king, studied all the doctrines of Brihaspati! O best of men, you know also the doctrines laid down by Ushanas.

data.v: तदहं श्रोतुमिच्छामि दण्ड उत्पद्यते कथम् । किं वापि पूर्वं जागर्ति किं वा परममुच्यते ॥
data.md: I wish to know what is the origin of Punishment? What also is said to be its end?

data.v: कथं क्षत्रियसंस्थश्च दण्डः संप्रत्यवस्थितः । ब्रूहि मे सुमहाप्राज्ञ ददाम्याचार्यवेतनम् ॥
data.md: How Came Punishment to depend upon the Kshatriya? Tell me all this, O you of great wisdom. I approach you as a disciple ready to give you the tuition fee.

data.v: शृणु राजन्यथा दण्डः संभूतो लोकसंग्रहः । प्रजाविनयरक्षार्थं धर्मस्यात्मा सनातनः ॥
data.md: Vasuhoma said Listen, O king, as to how Punishment, that upholder of the world, sprang up. It is the soul of righteousness, and eternal, and was created for preserving the proper government of all creatures.

data.v: ब्रह्मा यियक्षुर्भगवान्सर्वलोकपितामहः । ऋत्विजं नात्मना तुल्यं ददर्शेति हि नः श्रुतम् ॥
data.md: We have heard that once upon a time, the Grandfather of all the worlds, viz., the divine Brahmana, desiring to celebrate a sacrifice, could not find a priest equally qualified like himself.

data.v: स गर्भं शिरसा देवो वर्षपूगानधारयत् । पूर्णे वर्षसहस्रे तु स गर्भः क्षुवतोऽपतत् ॥
data.md: Therefore, he once conceived in his brain and held the foetus there for many long years. After a thousand years, the great god sneezed. In that act, the foetus dropped from his head.

data.v: स क्षुपो नाम संभूतः प्रजापतिररिंदम । ऋत्विगासीत्तदा राजन्यज्ञे तस्य महात्मनः ॥
data.md: The divine being, O chastiser of foes, who was thus born from Brahman passed by the name of Kshupa. Highly powerful be became a lord of creatures. That Kshupa officiated as priest, O king, in the sacrifice of the highsouled Grandfather.

data.v: तस्मिन्प्रवृत्ते सत्रे तु ब्रह्मणः पार्थिवर्षभ । हृष्टरूपप्रचारत्वाद्दण्डः सोऽन्तर्हितोऽभवत् ॥
data.md: Upon the commencement of that sacrifice, of Brahman, O best of kings, punishment disappeared on account of the visible form that the Grandfather was then obliged to assume.

data.v: तस्मिन्नन्तर्हिते चाथ प्रजानां संकरोऽभवत् । नैव कार्यं न चाकार्यं भोज्याभोज्यं न विद्यते ॥
data.md: Punishment having disappeared, a great confusion arose among all creatures. There was no longer any distinction between what should be done and what should not. All difference, again, between clean and unclean food disappeared.

data.v: पेयापेयं कुतः सिद्धिर्हिंसन्ति च परस्परम् । गम्यागम्यं तदा नासीत्परस्वं स्वं च वै समम् ॥
data.md: Men could not distinguish between what drink was allowable and what drink was not. All creatures began to injure one another. There were no restraints about the union of the sexes. All idea of property disappeared.

data.v: परस्परं विलुम्पन्ते सारमेया इवामिषम् । अबलं बलिनो जघ्नुर्निर्मर्यादमवर्तत ॥
data.md: All creatures began to rob, snatching meat from one another. The strong began to kill the weak. Nobody cared the least for his neighbour.

data.v: ततः पितामहो विष्णुं भगवन्तं सनातनम् । संपूज्य वरदं देवं महादेवमथाब्रवीत् ॥
data.md: Then, having adored the divine and eternal Vishnu, the grandfather addressed that great boon-giving god, saying,-You should, O Keshava, show mercy on the present occasion. Let it be so ordained by you that the confusion that has already set in may disappear.

data.v: अत्र साध्वनुकम्पां वै कर्तुमर्हसि केवलम् । संकरो न भवेदत्र यथा वै तद्विधीयताम् ॥
ततः स भगवान्ध्यात्वा चिरं शूलजटाधरः । आत्मानमात्मना दण्डमसृजद्देवसत्तमः ॥
data.md: Thus addressed, that foremost of gods, armed with an enormous Shula, thinking for some time, converted his ownself into the form of Punishment.

data.v: तस्माच्च धर्मचरणां नीतिं देवीं सरस्वतीम् । असृजद्दण्डनीतिः सा त्रिषु लोकेषु विश्रुता ॥
data.md: From that form, having Righteousness for its legs, the goddess Sarasvati created Dandaniti (Science of Punishment) which very soon became celebrated all over the world.

data.v: भूयः स भगवान्ध्यात्वा चिरं शूलवरायुधः । तस्य तस्य निकायस्य चकारैकैकमीशरम् ॥
data.md: Thereafter the great god armed with a huge Shula, having again reflected for sometime, appointed a few among the gods as the rulers of their respective classes.

data.v: देवानामीश्वरं चक्रे देवं दशशतेक्षणम् । यमं वैवस्वतं चापि पितॄणामकरोत्पतिम् ॥
data.md: It was then that he made the divine Indra of a thousand eyes the king of gods. Yama the son of Vivasvat was made the lord of the departed manes.

data.v: धनानां रक्षसां चापि कुबेरमपि चेश्वरम् । पर्वतानां पतिं मेरुं सरितां च महोदधिम् ॥
data.md: Kubera was made the lord of riches and of all the Rakshasas. Meru was made the king of the mountains, and Oceans was made the lord of the rivers.

data.v: अपां राज्ये सुराणां च विदधे वरुणं प्रभुम् । मृत्युं प्राणेश्वरमथो तेजसां च हुताशनम् ॥
data.md: The powerful Varuna was made the lord of the waters and of the Asuras. Death was made the lord of life and of all living creatures, and Fire was made the chief of all things possessed of energy.

data.v: रुद्राणामपि चेशानं गोप्तारं विदधे प्रभुः । महात्मानं महादेवं विशालाक्षं सनातनम् ॥
data.md: The powerful Ishana the great and eternal Mahadeva, of three eyes, was made the king of the Rudras.

data.v: वसिष्ठमीशं विप्राणां वसूनां जातवेदसम् । तेजसां भास्करं चक्रे नक्षत्राणां निशाकरम् ॥
data.md: Vashishtha was made the king of the Brahmanas, and Jatavedas was made the chief of the Vasus. Surya was made the lord of all luminous bodies and Chandramas was made the lord of Stars and constellations,

data.v: वीरुधामंशुमन्तं च भूतानां च प्रभुं वरम् । कुमारं द्वादशभुजं स्कन्दं राजानमादिशत् ॥
data.md: Anshumat was made the chief of all herbs, and the powerful and foremost of deities, viz., Kumara or Skanda, having twelve arms, was made the lord of all the spirits and ghosts.

data.v: कालं सर्वेशमकरोत्संहारविनयात्मकम् । मृत्योश्चतुर्विभागस्य दुःखस्य च सुखस्य च ॥
data.md: Time, containing the seeds of both origin and destruction was made the lord of all creatures, as also of the four parts of Death viz., weapons, diseases, Yama, and acts, and, lastly of grief and joy.

data.v: ईश्वरः सर्वदेहस्तु राजराजो धनाधिपः । सर्वेषामेव रुद्राणां शूलपाणिरिति श्रुतिः ॥
data.md: The Shrutis say that the great god Mahadeva, the lord of lords, O king, armed with Shula, is the lord of the Rudras.

data.v: तमेकं ब्रह्मणः पुत्रमनुजातं क्षुपं ददौ । प्रजानामधिपं श्रेष्ठं सर्वधर्मभृतामपि ॥
data.md: The rod of punishment was given to Brahmana's latest-born son, viz., Kshupa, the lord of all creatures and the foremost of the virtuous.

data.v: महादेवस्ततस्तस्मिन्वृत्ते यज्ञे यथाविधि । दण्डं धर्मस्य गोप्तारं विष्णवे सत्कृतं ददौ ॥
data.md: Upon the completion of that sacrifice according to due rites, Mahadeva after making proper reverence handed over Punishment, that protector of Righteousness, to Vishnu.

data.v: विष्णुरङ्गिरसे प्रादादङ्गिरा मुनिसत्तमः । प्रादादिन्द्रमरीचिभ्यां मरीचिर्भृगवे ददौ ॥
data.md: Vishnu gave it to Angiras, and Angiras, that foremost of ascetics, handed it over to Indra and Marichi. Marichi gave it to Bhrigu.

data.v: भृगुर्ददावृषिभ्यस्तु तं दण्डं धर्मसंहितम् । ऋषयो लोकपालेभ्यो लोकपालाः क्षुपाय च ॥
data.md: Bhrigu gave that rod intended for the protection of righteousness to all the Rishis. The Rishis gave it to the Regents of the quarters, and the Regents made it over again to Kshupa.

data.v: क्षुपस्तु मनवे प्रादादादित्यतनयाय च । पुत्रेभ्यः श्राद्धदेवस्तु सूक्ष्मधर्मार्थकारणात् । तं ददौ सूर्यपुत्रस्तु मनुर्वै रक्षणात्मकम् ॥
data.md: Kshupa then handed it over to Manu the son of Surya. The god of Shraddhas (viz., Manu), gave it to his sons for the sake of true righteousness and riches.

data.v: विभज्य दण्डः कर्तव्यो धर्मेण न यदृच्छया । दुर्वाचा निग्रहो बन्धो हिरण्यं बाह्यतःक्रिया ॥
data.md: Punishment should be meted out with discrimination, guided by righteousness and not by caprice. It is intended for checking the wicked. Fines and confiscation are intended for creating terror, and not for replenishing the king's treasury.

data.v: व्यङ्गत्वं च शरीरस्य वधो वा नाल्पकारणात् । शरीरपीडास्तास्तास्तु देहत्यागो विवासनम् ॥
data.md: The wounding of one's body or the infliction of death should not be made for trivial causes. The infliction of physical pain by various means, hurling from tops of mountains, and punishment also, should not be guided by similar causes.

data.v: आनुपूर्व्या च दण्डोऽसौ प्रजा जागर्ति पालयन् । इन्द्रो जागर्ति भगवानिन्द्रादग्निर्विभावसुः ॥
अग्नेर्जागर्ति वरुणो वरुणाच्च प्रजापतिः । प्रजापतेस्ततो धर्मो जागर्ति विनयात्मकः ॥
धर्माच्च ब्रह्मणः पुत्रो व्यवसायः सनातनः । व्यवसायात्ततस्तेजो जागर्ति परिपालयन् ॥
ओषध्यस्तेजसस्तस्मादोषधिभ्यश्च पर्वताः । पर्वतेभ्यश्च जागर्ति रसो रसगुणात्तथा ॥
जागर्ति निरृतिर्देवी ज्योतींषि निरृतेरपि । वेदाः प्रतिष्ठा ज्योतिर्भ्यस्ततो हयशिराः प्रभुः ॥
ब्रह्मा पितामहस्तस्माज्जागर्ति प्रभुरव्ययः । पितामहान्महादेवो जागर्ति भगवाञ्शिवः ॥
विश्वेदेवाः शिवाच्चापि विश्वेभ्यश्च तथर्षयः । ऋषिभ्यो भगवान्सोमः सोमाद्देवाः सनातनाः ॥
देवेभ्यो ब्राह्मणा लोके जाग्रतीत्युपधारय । ब्राह्मणेभ्यश्च राजन्या लोकान्रक्षन्ति धर्मतः । स्थावरं जङ्गमं चैव क्षत्रियेभ्यः सनातनम् ॥
data.md: After the Brahmanas, the Kshatriyas are piously protecting all creatures. The universe, consisting of mobile and immobile creatures, is kept awake by the Kshatriyas.

data.v: प्रजा जाग्रति लोकेऽस्मिन्दण्डो जागर्ति तासु च । सर्वसंक्षेपको दण्डः पितामहसमः प्रभुः ॥
data.md: Creatures are kept awake in this world, and Punishment is awake is among them. Effulgent like the Grandfather himself, Punishment keeps together and maintains everything.

data.v: जागर्ति कालः पूर्वं च मध्ये चान्ते च भारत । ईश्वरः सर्वलोकस्य महादेवः प्रजापतिः ॥
data.md: Time, O Bharata, is always awake, in the beginning, the middle, and the end. The lord of all the worlds, the lord of all creatures, the powerful and blessed Mahadeva, the god of gods, is always awake, He passes also by the names Kapardin, Shankara, Rudra, Bhava, Sthanu, and the lord of Uma.

data.v: देवदेवः शिवः शर्वो जागर्ति सततं प्रभुः । कपर्दी शंकरो रुद्रो भवः स्थाणुरुमापतिः ॥
इत्येष दण्डो विख्यात आदौ मध्ये तथावरे । भूमिपालो यथान्यायं वर्तेतानेन धर्मवित् ॥
data.md: Thus Punishment also keeps awake in the beginning, the middle and the end. A virtuous king should duly rule, guided by Punishment.

data.v: इतीदं वसुहोमस्य शृणुयाद्यो मतं नरः । श्रुत्वा च सम्यग्वर्तेत स कामानाप्नुयान्नृपः ॥
data.md: The person who listens to this teaching of Vasuhoma, and having listened to it behaves according to its trend, is sure to acquire the fruition of all his desires.

data.v: इति ते सर्वमाख्यातं यो दण्डो मनुजर्षभ । नियन्ता सर्वलोकस्य धर्माक्रान्तस्य भारत ॥
data.md: I have now, O foremost of men, told you everything as to who punishment is, that restrainer of the universe which is governed by righteousness.

data.v: तात धर्मार्थकामानां श्रोतुमिच्छामि निश्चयम् । लोकयात्रा हि कार्त्स्न्येन त्रिष्वेतेषु प्रतिष्ठिता ॥
data.md: Yudhishthira said I wish, O sire, to hear the final conclusions about Virtue, Profit and Pleasure. Depending upon which of these does life proceed?

data.v: धर्मार्थकामाः किंमूलास्त्रयाणां प्रभवश्च कः । अन्योन्यं चानुषज्जन्ते वर्तन्ते च पृथक्पृथक् ॥
data.md: What are origins of Virtue, Profit, and Pleasure? What is again the out come to those three? They are sometimes seen intermixed with one another, and sometimes to exist separately and independently of one another,

data.v: यदा ते स्युः सुमनसो लोकसंस्थार्थनिश्चये । कालप्रभवसंस्थासु सज्जन्ते च त्रयस्तदा ॥
data.md: When men in this world try with pure hearts to gain Profit with the help of Virtue, then those three, viz., Virtue, Profit, and Pleasure, may be seen to exist in a state of union regarding time, cause, and action.

data.v: धर्ममूलस्तु देहोऽर्थः कामोऽर्थफलमुच्यते । संकल्पमूलास्ते सर्वे संकल्पो विषयात्मकः ॥
data.md: Profit originates f um virtue, and Pleasure is the fruit of Profit. All the three again originate from Will. Will is connected with the objects.

data.v: विषयाश्चैव कार्त्स्न्येन सर्व आहारसिद्धये । मूलमेतत्त्रिवर्गस्य निवृत्तिर्मोक्ष उच्यते ॥
data.md: All objects exist in a body for gratifying the desire of enjoyment. Upon these dependent the threefold objects of life. Renunciation of all objects is liberation.

data.v: धर्मः शरीरसंगुप्तिर्धर्मार्थं चार्थ इष्यते । कामो रतिफलश्चात्र सर्वे चैते रजस्वलाः ॥
data.md: It is said that Virtue is sought for the protection of the body, and Profit is for the acquisition of Virtue. Pleasure is merely the gratification of the sense. All the three are, therefore, pervaded the quality of Rajas (darkness).

data.v: संनिकृष्टांश्चरेदेनान्न चैनान्मनसा त्यजेत् । विमुक्तस्तमसा सर्वान्धर्मादीन्कामनैष्ठिकान् ॥
data.md: Virtue, Profit, and Pleasure, when sought for the sake of heaven and such other rewards, are considered remote, because the rewards themselves are remote. They are near when sought, however, for the sake of Knowledge of Self. One should seek them for the purity of soul. One should not renounce them even in mind. If Virtue, Profit, and Pleasure are to be abandoned, one should abandon them when one has liberated one's self by ascetic penances.

data.v: श्रेष्ठबुद्धिस्त्रिवर्गस्य यदयं प्राप्नुयात्क्षणात् । बुद्ध्या बुध्येदिहार्थे न तदह्ना तु निकृष्टया ॥
data.md: The aim of the threefold objects is emancipation. I wish men could attain it. One's acts, undertaking and completed with even the " help of intelligence may or may not yield the expected fruits.

data.v: अपध्यानमलो धर्मो मलोऽर्थस्य निगूहनम् । संप्रमोदमलः कामो भूयः स्वगुणवर्तितः ॥
data.md: The defeat of Virtue consists in the desire of reward; that of Profit consists in amassing it; when freed from these impurities, they yield mighty fruits.

data.v: अत्राप्युदाहरन्तीममितिहासं पुरातनम् । कामन्दस्य च संवादमङ्गारिष्ठस्य चोभयोः ॥
data.md: Bhishma said-Regarding it is cited the old story of the discourse between the Ocean and the Rivers.

data.v: कामन्दमृषिमासीनमभिवाद्य नराधिपः । अङ्गारिष्ठोऽथ पप्रच्छ कृत्वा समयपर्ययम् ॥
data.md: One day having waited for the opportunity, king Angarishtha saluted the Rishi Kamanda as he was seated at his ease, and put to him the

data.v: यः पापं कुरुते राजा काममोहबलात्कृतः । प्रत्यासन्नस्य तस्यर्षे किं स्यात्पापप्रणाशनम् ॥
data.md: If a king, under the influence of lust and folly, commits sin for which he afterwards repents, how, O Rishi, can those sins be destroyed.

data.v: अधर्मो धर्म इति ह योऽज्ञानादाचरेदिह । तं चापि प्रथितं लोके कथं राजा निवर्तयेत् ॥
data.md: If again a man, guided by ignorance, does what is sinful in the belief that he is acting piously, how shall the king suppress that sin prevalent among men?

data.v: यो धर्मार्थौ समुत्सृज्य काममेवानुवर्तते । स धर्मार्थपरित्यागात्प्रज्ञानाशमिहार्छति ॥
data.md: Kamanda said That man, who renouncing Virtue and Profit, pursues only Pleasure, reaps as the result of such conduct the destruction of his intelligence.

data.v: प्रज्ञाप्रणाशको मोहस्तथा धर्मार्थनाशकः । तस्मान्नास्तिकता चैव दुराचारश्च जायते ॥
data.md: The destruction of intelligence is followed by carelessness which at once destroys both Virtue and Profit. Such carelessness, beget dreadful atheism and systematic wickedness.

data.v: दुराचारान्यदा राजा प्रदुष्टान्न नियच्छति । तस्मादुद्विजते लोकः सर्पाद्वेश्मगतादिव ॥
data.md: If the king does not subdue those wicked men of sinful conduct, all good subjects then live in dread of him like a person living in a room within which a snake has concealed itself.

data.v: तं प्रजा नानुवर्तन्ते ब्राह्मणा न च साधवः । ततः संक्षयमाप्नोति तथा वध्यत्वमेति च ॥
data.md: The subjects do not follow such a king. Brahmanas and all pious persons also do the same. As a consequence the king incurs grave danger, and ultimately the risk of his life.

data.v: अपध्वस्तस्त्ववमतो दुःखं जीवति जीवितम् । जीवेच्च यदपध्वस्तस्तच्छुद्धं मरणं भवेत् ॥
data.md: Laden with infamy and insult, he has to carry on a miserable existence. A life of infamy, however, is tantamount to death.

data.v: अत्रैतदाहुराचार्याः पापस्य च निबर्हणम् । सेवितव्या त्रयी विद्या सत्कारो ब्राह्मणेषु च ॥
data.md: Men well read in the scriptures have laid down the following expedients for suppressing sin. The king should always study the three Vedas. He should respect the Brahmanas and do them good.

data.v: महामना भवेद्धर्मे विवहेच्च महाकुले । ब्राह्मणांश्चापि सेवेत क्षमायुक्तान्मनस्विनः ॥
data.md: He should be given to righteousness. He should make alliance with high families. He should serve the great Brahmanas endued with the virtue of forgiveness.

data.v: जपेदुदकशीलः स्यात्सुमुखो नान्यदास्थितः । धर्मान्वितान्संप्रविशेद्बहिः कृत्वैव दुष्कृतीन् ॥
data.md: He should perform ablutions and recite sacred Mantras and thus spend his days happily. Banishing all wicked subjects from himself and his kingdom, he should live with virtuous men.

data.v: प्रसादयेन्मधुरया वाचाप्यथ च कर्मणा । इत्यस्मीति वदेन्नित्यं परेषां कीर्तयन्गुणान् ॥
data.md: He should please all persons by. sweet words or good acts. He should say to all,-I am yours,-and declare the virtues of even his enemies.

data.v: अपापो ह्येवमाचारः क्षिप्रं बहुमतो भवेत् । पापान्यपि च कृच्छ्राणि शमयेन्नात्र संशयः ॥
data.md: By behaving thus he may soon cleanse himself of his sins, and gain the high esteem of all. Forsooth, by such a conduct all his sins will be destroyed.

data.v: गुरवोऽपि परं धर्मं यद्ब्रूयुस्तत्तथा कुरु । गुरूणां हि प्रसादाद्धि श्रेयः परमवाप्स्यसि ॥
data.md: You should satisfy all those great duties which your seniors and preceptors would indicate. You are sure to acquire, great blessings through the grace of your seniors and preceptors.'

data.v: इमे जना नरश्रेष्ठ प्रशंसन्ति सदा भुवि । धर्मस्य शीलमेवादौ ततो मे संशयो महान् ॥
data.md: Yudhishthira said All persons on Earth, O foremost of men, speak highly of virtuous conduct, I have, however, great misgivings regarding this subject of their praise.

data.v: यदि तच्छक्यमस्माभिर्ज्ञातुं धर्मभृतां वर । श्रोतुमिच्छामि तत्सर्वं यथैतदुपलभ्यते ॥
data.md: If the subject be not far from our comprehension, O foremost of virtuous men, I wish to hear everything about the way in which virtuous conduct can be acquired.

data.v: कथं नु प्राप्यते शीलं श्रोतुमिच्छामि भारत । किंलक्षणं च तत्प्रोक्तं ब्रूहि मे वदतां वर ॥
data.md: How is, that conduct acquired, O Bharata! I wish to hear it. Tell me also, O foremost of orators, what are the characteristics of that conduct.

data.v: पुरा दुर्योधनेनेह धृतराष्ट्राय मानद । आख्यातं तप्यमानेन श्रियं दृष्ट्वा तथागताम् ॥
data.md: Bhishma said 'Formerly, O givers of honours, Duryodhana while burning within at your and your brothers' prosperity at Indraprastha, and for the jeers he received for his mistakes at the grand palace, had asked his father Dhritarashtra the same question. Hear what transpired at that time, O Bharata.

data.v: इन्द्रप्रस्थे महाराज तव सभ्रातृकस्य ह । सभायां चावहसनं तत्सर्वं शृणु भारत ॥
भवतस्तां सभां दृष्ट्वा समृद्धिं चाप्यनुत्तमाम् । दुर्योधनस्तदासीनः सर्वं पित्रे न्यवेदयत् ॥
data.md: Having seen that grand palace and that great prosperity of yours, Duryodhana, while sitting before his father described to him of all he had seen.

data.v: श्रुत्वा च धृतराष्ट्रोऽपि दुर्योधनवचस्तदा । अब्रवीत्कर्णसहितं दुर्योधनमिदं वचः ॥
data.md: Having heard the words of Duryodhana, Dhritarashtra, addressing his son and Karna, replied to him as follows.

data.v: किमर्थं तप्यसे पुत्र श्रोतुमिच्छामि तत्त्वतः । श्रुत्वा त्वामनुनेष्यामि यदि सम्यग्भविष्यसि ॥
data.md: Dhritarashtra said Why do you grieve, O son! I wish to hear the cause fully. If after hearing the reasons they appear to be sufficient, I shall then try to instruct you.

data.v: यथा त्वं महदैश्वर्यं प्राप्तः परपुरंजय । किंकरा भ्रातरः सर्वे मित्राः संबन्धिनस्तथा ॥
data.md: O subjugator of hostile towns, you too have acquired great affluence. All your brothers are ever obedient to your, as also all your friends and relatives.

data.v: आच्छादयसि प्रावारानश्नासि पिशितोदनम् । आजानेया वहन्ति त्वां कस्माच्छोचसि पुत्रक ॥
data.md: You are clad in the best robes. You take the richest food. Horses of the best species bear you. Why then have you become pale and emaciated?

data.v: दश तानि सहस्राणि स्नातकानां महात्मनाम् । भुञ्जते रुक्मपात्रीषु युधिष्ठिरनिवेशने ॥
data.md: Duryodhana said Ten thousands of great Snataka Brahmanas daily take their food at Yudhishthira's palace from plates of gold.

data.v: दृष्ट्वा च तां सभां दिव्यां दिव्यपुष्पफलान्विताम् । अश्वांस्तित्तिरकल्माषान्रत्नानि विविधानि च ॥
data.md: Seeing his beautiful palaces adorned with excellent flowers and fruits, his horses of the Tittiri and the Kalmasha breeds, his dresses of various sorts, indeed, seeing that high prosperity of my enemies, viz., the sons of Pandu,-a prosperity resembling that of Vaishravana himself,-I am burning with grief, O Bharata!-

data.v: दृष्ट्वा तां पाण्डवेयानामृद्धिमिन्द्रोपमां शुभाम् । अमित्राणां सुमहतीमनुशोचामि मानद ॥
यदीच्छसि श्रियं तात यादृशीं तां युधिष्ठिरे । विशिष्टां वा नरव्याघ्र शीलवान्भव पुत्रक ॥
data.md: Dhritarashtra said If you wish, O sire, to acquire prosperity like that of Yudhishthira or that which is even superior to it, do you then, O son, try to be of virtuous conduct.

data.v: शीलेन हि त्रयो लोकाः शक्या जेतुं न संशयः । न हि किंचिदसाध्यं वै लोके शीलवतां भवेत् ॥
data.md: Forsooth, one may, by his conduct alone, conquer the three words. There is nothing which virtuous persons cannot obtain.

data.v: एकरात्रेण मान्धाता त्र्यहेण जनमेजयः । सप्तरात्रेण नाभागः पृथिवीं प्रतिपेदिवान् ॥
data.md: Mandhata conquered the whole word in only one night, Janamejaya, in course of three; and Nabhaga, in course of seven.

data.v: एते हि पार्थिवाः सर्वे शीलवन्तो दमान्विताः । अतस्तेषां गुणक्रीता वसुधा स्वयमागमत् ॥
data.md: All these kings were endued with mercy and virtuous conduct. Therefore, the Earth came to them at their will, won over by their virtues!

data.v: अत्राप्युदाहरन्तीममितिहासं पुरातनम् । नारदेन पुरा प्रोक्तं शीलमाश्रित्य भारत ॥
data.md: Regarding it is cited the discourse that took place in days of yore between Kamandaka and Angarishtha.

data.v: प्रह्रादेन हृतं राज्यं महेन्द्रस्य महात्मनः । शीलमाश्रित्य दैत्येन त्रैलोक्यं च वशीकृतम् ॥
data.md: In days of yore, the Daitya Prahlada, by the merit of his conduct, snatched from the great Indra his sovereignty and brought the three worlds under subjection.

data.v: ततो बृहस्पतिं शक्रः प्राञ्जलिः समुपस्थितः । उवाच च महाप्राज्ञः श्रेय इच्छामि वेदितुम् ॥
data.md: Shakra then, with joined hands, approached Brihaspati. Endued with great wisdom, the god of the celestials addressed to the great preceptor, saying,-I desire you to tell me the source of happiness.

data.v: ततो बृहस्पतिस्तस्मै ज्ञानं नैःश्रेयसं परम् । कथयामास भगवान्देवेन्द्राय कुरूद्वह ॥
data.md: Thus accosted, Brihaspati said to him that Knowledge is the source of the greatest happiness.

data.v: एतावच्छ्रेय इत्येव बृहस्पतिरभाषत । इन्द्रस्तु भूयः पप्रच्छ क्व विशेषो भवेदिति ॥
data.md: Indeed, Brihaspati pointed out knowledge to be the source of supreme happiness. Indra, however, once more asked him as to whether there was any thing superior to that.

data.v: विशेषोऽस्ति महांस्तात भार्गवस्य महात्मनः । तत्रागमय भद्रं ते भूय एव पुरंदर ॥
data.md: Brihaspati said There is some thing, O son, which is still higher. The great Bhargava (Ushanas) will instruct your better. Go to him, blessed be you, and enquire of him, O king of the celestials!

data.v: आत्मनस्तु ततः श्रेयो भार्गवात्सुमहायशाः । ज्ञानमागमयत्प्रीत्या पुनः स परमद्युतिः ॥
data.md: Endued with great ascetic merit and effulgence, the king of the celestials then went to Bhargava and acquired from him, with a gratified heart, a knowledge of that which was to his greatest good.

data.v: तेनापि समनुज्ञातो भार्गवेण महात्मना । श्रेयोऽस्तीति पुनर्भूयः शुक्रमाह शतक्रतुः ॥
data.md: Acquiring the permission of the great Bhargava, the celebrator of a hundred sacrifices once more asked the sage as to whether there was anything superior to what the sage had already told him.

data.v: भार्गवस्त्वाह धर्मज्ञः प्रह्रादस्य महात्मनः । ज्ञानमस्ति विशेषेण ततो हृष्टश्च सोऽभवत् ॥
data.md: The omniscient Bhargava said,-The great Prahlada has better knowledge!-Learning this, Indra became highly pleased.

data.v: स ततो ब्राह्मणो भूत्वा प्रह्रादं पाकशासनः । सृत्वा प्रोवाच मेधावी श्रेय इच्छामि वेदितुम् ॥
data.md: The chastiser of Paka, endued with supreme intelligence, assumed the form of a Brahman and going to Prahlada, asked him saying-I desire to hear what conduces to felicity.

data.v: प्रह्रादस्त्वब्रवीद्विप्रं क्षणो नास्ति द्विजर्षभ । त्रैलोक्यराज्ये सक्तस्य ततो नोपदिशामि ते ॥
data.md: Prahlada answered the Brahmana, saying,-O chief of the twice-born, I have no time, being wholly engaged with the task of ruling the three worlds!-I cannot therefore, instruct you.

data.v: ब्राह्मणस्त्वब्रवीद्वाक्यं कस्मिन्काले क्षणो भवेत् । ततोपदिष्टमिच्छामि यद्यत्कार्यान्तरं भवेत् ॥
data.md: The Brahmana said,-O king when you may have leisure, I wish to listen to your instructions about that conduct which yields good!

data.v: ततः प्रीतोऽभवद्राजा प्रह्रादो ब्रह्मवादिने । तथेत्युक्त्वा शुभे काले ज्ञानतत्त्वं ददौ तदा ॥
data.md: At this answer, king Prahlada became pleased with that Brahmavadin. Saying,-So be it!-he availed of a favourable opportunity for delivering to the Brahma the truths of knowledge.

data.v: ब्राह्मणोऽपि यथान्यायं गुरुवृत्तिमनुत्तमाम् । चकार सर्वभावेन यद्वत्स मनसेच्छति ॥
data.md: The Brahmana duly treated Prahlada as a disciple should his preceptor, and began with his whole heart to do what Prahlada wished.

data.v: पृष्टश्च तेन बहुशः प्राप्तं कथमरिंदम । त्रैलोक्यराज्यं धर्मज्ञ कारणं तद्ब्रवीहि मे ॥
data.md: Many a time the Brahmana enquired, saying,O chastiser of enemies by what means have you been able to acquire the sovereignty of the three worlds? Tell me, O pious king, what those means are!-Prahlada, O king, answered the question of the Brahmana.

data.v: नासूयामि द्विजश्रेष्ठ राजास्मीति कदाचन । कव्यानि वदतां तात संयच्छामि वहामि च ॥
data.md: Prahlada said I do not, O twice-born one, feel any pride for my being a king, nor do I entertain any hostile feeling towards the Brahmanas! On the other hand, I accept and follow the policy they describe to me based upon the teachings of Shukra.

data.v: ते विस्रब्धाः प्रभाषन्ते संयच्छन्ति च मां सदा । ते मा कव्यपदे सक्तं शुश्रूषुमनसूयकम् ॥
data.md: Full confident they say to me what they wish to say, and restrain me from unrighteous or improper courses. I am ever obedient to the teachings of Shukra. I wait upon and serve the Brahmanas and my elders. I bear no malice.

data.v: धर्मात्मानं जितक्रोधं संयतं संयतेन्द्रियम् । समाचिन्वन्ति शास्तारः क्षौद्रं मध्विव मक्षिकाः ॥
data.md: I am of righteous soul. I have conquered anger. I am self-controlled, and all my senses are under restraint. Those twice-born ones that are my instructors give me wholesome advice like bees dropping honey into the cells of their comb.

data.v: सोऽहं वागग्रपिष्टानां रसानामवलेहिता । स्वजात्यानधितिष्ठामि नक्षत्राणीव चन्द्रमाः ॥
data.md: I taste the ambrosia dropped by those learned men, and like the Moon among the stars I live among the members of my family.

data.v: एतत्पृथिव्याममृतमेतच्चक्षुरनुत्तमम् । यद्ब्राह्मणमुखे कव्यमेतच्छ्रुत्वा प्रवर्तते ॥
data.md: Even listening to the teachings of Shukra from the lips of Brahmanas and following them in practise, is this nectar on Earth, even this is the clearest eye.

data.v: एतावच्छ्रेय इत्याह प्रह्रादो ब्रह्मवादिनम् । शुश्रूषितस्तेन तदा दैत्येन्द्रो वाक्यमब्रवीत् ॥
data.md: The good of a man consists in these, Thus said Prahlada to that utterer of Brahma. Served dutifully by him, the chief of the Asuras once more said,-O foremost of twice-born ones, I am highly pleased with you for your dutiful conduct towards me. Ask of me the boon you wish, blessed be you, for I shall grant you what you will ask.

data.v: यथावद्गुरुवृत्त्या ते प्रीतोऽस्मि द्विजसत्तम । वरं वृणीष्व भद्रं ते प्रदातास्मि न संशयः ॥
data.md: The good of a man consists in these, Thus said Prahlada to that utterer of Brahma. Served dutifully by him, the chief of the Asuras once more said,-O foremost of twice-born ones, I am highly pleased with you for your dutiful conduct towards me. Ask of me the boon you wish, blessed be you, for I shall grant you what you will ask.

data.v: कृतमित्येव दैत्येन्द्रमुवाच स च वै द्विजः । प्रह्रादस्त्वब्रवीत्प्रीतो गृह्यतां वर इत्युत ॥
data.md: The Brahmana answered the king of the Asuras saying,-Very well. I will obey you.-Prahlada, pleased with him, said,-Take what you wish.

data.v: यदि राजन्प्रसन्नस्त्वं मम चेच्छसि चेद्धितम् । भवतः शीलमिच्छामि प्राप्तुमेष वरो मम ॥
data.md: The Brahmana said for. If, O king, you have been pleased with me and if you wish to do what is agreeable to me, I wish then to acquire your behaviour? This is the boon that I pray

data.v: ततः प्रीतश्च दैत्येन्द्रो भयं चास्याभवन्महत् । वरे प्रदिष्टे विप्रेण नाल्पतेजायमित्युत ॥
data.md: At this, though pleased, Prahlada became stricken with a great fear. Indeed when this boon was indicated by the Brahmana, the Asura king thought that the solicitor could not be an ordinary person.

data.v: एवमस्त्विति तं प्राह प्रह्रादो विस्मितस्तदा । उपाकृत्य तु विप्राय वरं दुःखान्वितोऽभवत् ॥
data.md: Wondering much, Prahlada at last said,-Let it be so!-Having, however, granted the boon, the Asura king became filled with grief.

data.v: दत्ते वरे गते विप्रे चिन्तासीन्महती ततः । प्रह्रादस्य महाराज निश्चयं न च जग्मिवान् ॥
data.md: Having received the boon, the Brahmana went away, but Prahlada, O king, was stricken with a deep anxiety and knew not what to do.

data.v: तस्य चिन्तयतस्तात छायाभूतं महाद्युते । तेजो विग्रहवत्तात शरीरमजहात्तदा ॥
तमपृच्छन्महाकायं प्रह्रादः को भवानिति । प्रत्याह ननु शीलोऽस्मि त्यक्तो गच्छाम्यहं त्वया ॥
data.md: While the Asura king sat brooding over the matter, a flame of light came out of his person. It had a shadowy form of great effulgence and huge proportions. Prahlada asked the form, saying,-Who are You?-The form answered, saying-—I am the embodiment of your conduct. Renounced by you I am going away.

data.v: तस्मिन्द्विजवरे राजन्वत्स्याम्यहमनिन्दितम् । योऽसौ शिष्यत्वमागम्य त्वयि नित्यं समाहितः । इत्युक्त्वान्तर्हितं तद्वै शक्रं चान्वविशत्प्रभो ॥
data.md: I shall henceforth, O king, dwell in that blameless and foremost of Brahmanas who had become your devoted disciple!-Having said these words, the form vanished and soon after entered the body of Shakra.

data.v: तस्मिंस्तेजसि याते तु तादृग्रूपस्ततोऽपरः । शरीरान्निःसृतस्तस्य को भवानिति चाब्रवीत् ॥
data.md: After the disappearance of that form, another of similar form issued out of Prahlada's body. The Daitya king addressing it, said,-Who are you?

data.v: धर्मं प्रह्राद मां विद्धि यत्रासौ द्विजसत्तमः । तत्र यास्यामि दैत्येन्द्र यतः शीलं ततो ह्यहम् ॥
data.md: The form answered, saying,-Know me, O Prahlada, for the embodiment of Righteousness, I shall go there where that foremost of Brahmanas is, for, o king of the Daityas, I reside there where Conduct lives!

data.v: ततोऽपरो महाराज प्रज्वलन्निव तेजसा । शरीरान्निःसृतस्तस्य प्रह्रादस्य महात्मनः ॥
data.md: Upon the disappearance of Righteousness, a third highly effulgent form, O monarch, issued out of the body of the great Prahlada.

data.v: को भवानिति पृष्टश्च तमाह स महाद्युतिः । सत्यमस्म्यसुरेन्द्राग्र्य यास्येऽहं धर्ममन्विह ॥
data.md: Asked by Prahlada as to who he was, that highly effulgent form answered, sayingKnow, O king of the Daityas, that I am Truth. I shall leave you, following the way of Righteousness!

data.v: तस्मिन्ननुगते धर्मं पुरुषे पुरुषोऽपरः । निश्चक्राम ततस्तस्मात्पृष्टश्चाह महात्मना । वृत्तं प्रह्राद मां विद्धि यतः सत्यं ततो ह्यहम् ॥
data.md: After Truth had left Prahlada, following Righteousness, another great person issued out of Prahlada's body. Asked by the Daitya king, the mighty being answered, being answered, I am the embodiment of good works. Know, O Prahlada, that I live there were the Truth lives!

data.v: तस्मिन्गते महाश्वेतः शरीरात्तस्य निर्ययौ । पृष्टश्चाह बलं विद्धि यतो वृत्तमहं ततः । इत्युक्त्वा च ययौ तत्र यतो वृत्तं नराधिप ॥
data.md: After this one had left Prahlada, another being come out, giving vent to loud and deep cries. Addressed by Prahlada, he answered,-Know that I am Power. I live there where good works are.

data.v: ततः प्रभामयी देवी शरीरात्तस्य निर्ययौ । तामपृच्छत्स दैत्येन्द्रः सा श्रीरित्येवमब्रवीत् ॥
उषितास्मि सुखं वीर त्वयि सत्यपराक्रमे । त्वया त्यक्ता गमिष्यामि बलं यत्र ततो ह्यहम् ॥
data.md: The Daitya king asked her and she answered him saying that she was the embodiment of Prosperity, adding,-I lived in you, O hero, O you of prowess incapable of being baffled. Renounced by you, I shall follow Power.

data.v: ततो भयं प्रादुरासीत्प्रह्रादस्य महात्मनः । अपृच्छत च तां भूयः क्व यासि कमलालये ॥
data.md: The great Prahlada, stricken with fear, once more asked the goddess, saying,-Where do you go, O goddess, O you that live amid lotuses?

data.v: त्वं हि सत्यव्रता देवी लोकस्य परमेश्वरी । कश्चासौ ब्राह्मणश्रेष्ठस्तत्त्वमिच्छामि वेदितुम् ॥
data.md: You are ever devoted to truth, O goddess, and you are the foremost of deities. Who is that foremost of Brahmanas? I wish to know the truth!

data.v: स शक्रो ब्रह्मचारी च यस्त्वया चोपशिक्षितः । त्रैलोक्ये ते यदैश्वर्यं तत्तेनापहृतं प्रभो ॥
data.md: The goddess of Prosperity said Practising the vow of Brahmacharya, that Brahmana who was instructed by you was Shakra. O foremost one, he robbed you of that sovereignty which you had over the three worlds.

data.v: शीलेन हि त्वया लोकाः सर्वे धर्मज्ञ निर्जिताः । तद्विज्ञाय महेन्द्रेण तव शीलं हृतं प्रभो ॥
data.md: O Righteous one, it was by your conduct that you had reduced the three worlds to subjection. Knowing this the king of the gods robbed you of your conduct!

data.v: धर्मः सत्यं तथा वृत्तं बलं चैव तथा ह्यहम् । शीलमूला महाप्राज्ञ सदा नास्त्यत्र संशयः ॥
data.md: Righteousness and Truth and good works and Power and myself, O you of great wisdom, all originate from conduct.

data.v: एवमुक्त्वा गता तु श्रीस्ते च सर्वे युधिष्ठिर । दुर्योधनस्तु पितरं भूय एवाब्रवीदिदम् ॥
data.md: Bhishma said Having said these words, the goddess of Prosperity went away, as also all the rest, O Yudhishthira. Once more addressing his father.

data.v: शीलस्य तत्त्वमिच्छामि वेत्तुं कौरवनन्दन । प्राप्यते च यथा शीलं तमुपायं वदस्व मे ॥
data.md: Duryodhana said O delighter of the Kurus, I wish to know the truth about conduct. Tell me the means by which it may be acquired.

data.v: सोपायं पूर्वमुद्दिष्टं प्रह्रादेन महात्मना । संक्षेपतस्तु शीलस्य शृणु प्राप्तिं नराधिप ॥
data.md: Dhritarashtra said Those means were described by the great Prahlada while discoursing to Indra. Listen, however, O king, as to how in brief conduct may be acquired.

data.v: अद्रोहः सर्वभूतेषु कर्मणा मनसा गिरा । अनुग्रहश्च दानं च शीलमेतत्प्रशस्यते ॥
data.md: Abstention from injury, by act, thought, and word to all creatures, mercy, and gift, constitute the praise-worthy behaviour.

data.v: यदन्येषां हितं न स्यादात्मनः कर्म पौरुषम् । अपत्रपेत वा येन न तत्कुर्यात्कथंचन ॥
data.md: That act or exertion which does not do good to other, or that act for which one has to feel shame, should never be done.

data.v: तत्तु कर्म तथा कुर्याद्येन श्लाघेत संसदि । एतच्छीलं समासेन कथितं कुरुसत्तम ॥
data.md: That act, on the other hand, should be done for which one may be lauded in society. O best of the Kurus, I have now told you briefly as to what conduct is.

data.v: यद्यप्यशीला नृपते प्राप्नुवन्ति क्वचिच्छ्रियम् । न भुञ्जते चिरं तात समूलाश्च पतन्ति ते ॥
data.md: If, O king, wicked persons do ever acquire prosperity, they do not enjoy it long, O son, and are soon rooted out.

data.v: एतद्विदित्वा तत्त्वेन शीलवान्भव पुत्रक । यदीच्छसि श्रियं तात सुविशिष्टां युधिष्ठिरात् ॥
data.md: Dhritarashtra said Knowing all this truly, do you, O son, be of good conduct, if you wish to obtain greater prosperity than Yudhishthira.'

data.v: एतत्कथितवान्पुत्रे धृतराष्ट्रो नराधिप । एतत्कुरुष्व कौन्तेय ततः प्राप्स्यसि तत्फलम् ॥
data.md: Bhishma said This was what king Dhritarashtra said to his son. Do you follow these instructions, O son of Kunti, and you will then surely acquire their fruit.

data.v: शीलं प्रधानं पुरुषे कथितं ते पितामह । कथमाशा समुत्पन्ना या च सा तद्वदस्व मे ॥
data.md: Yudhishthira said You have said, O grandfather, that conduct is the first thing (for a man). Whence, however, does Hope arise? Tell me what it is.

data.v: संशयो मे महानेष समुत्पन्नः पितामह । छेत्ता च तस्य नान्योऽस्ति त्वत्तः परपुरंजय ॥
data.md: This great doubt has occupied my mind. There is no other person than you, Osubjugator of hostile towns, who can remove it!

data.v: पितामहाशा महती ममासीद्धि सुयोधने । प्राप्ते युद्धे तु यद्युक्तं तत्कर्तायमिति प्रभो ॥
data.md: O grandfather, I had great hope about Suyodhana that when a battle was about to take place, he would, O lord, do what was proper.

data.v: सर्वस्याशा सुमहती पुरुषस्योपजायते । तस्यां विहन्यमानायां दुःखो मृत्युरसंशयम् ॥
data.md: Hope is tne sheet-anchor of every man. When that hope is destroyed, great grief follows which, forsooth, is almost equal to death itself.

data.v: सोऽहं हताशो दुर्बुद्धिः कृतस्तेन दुरात्मना । धार्तराष्ट्रेण राजेन्द्र पश्य मन्दात्मतां मम ॥
data.md: Fool that I am, Dhritarashtra's wicked son, Duryodhana, destroyed the hope I had entertained. Mark, O king, the foolishness of my mind.

data.v: आशां महत्तरां मन्ये पर्वतादपि सद्रुमात् । आकाशादपि वा राजन्नप्रमेयैव वा पुनः ॥
data.md: I think that hope is bigger than a mountain with all its trees. Or, perhaps, it is bigger than the sky itself. Or, perhaps, O king, it is really immeasurable.

data.v: एषा चैव कुरुश्रेष्ठ दुर्विचिन्त्या सुदुर्लभा । दुर्लभत्वाच्च पश्यामि किमन्यद्दुर्लभं ततः ॥
data.md: Hope, O chief of the Kurus, is highly difficult of being understood and equally difficult of being conquered. Seeing this last attribute of Hope, I ask, what else is so unconquerable as this?

data.v: अत्र ते वर्तयिष्यामि युधिष्ठिर निबोध तत् । इतिहासं सुमित्रस्य निर्वृत्तमृषभस्य च ॥
data.md: Bhishma said I shall describe to you, O Yudhishthira, regarding it, the discourse between Sumitra and Rishabha that took place in days of yore, Listen to it!

data.v: सुमित्रो नाम राजर्षिर्हैहयो मृगयां गतः । ससार स मृगं विद्ध्वा बाणेन नतपर्वणा ॥
data.md: A royal sage of the Haihaya family, Sumitra by namre, went a hunting. Having pierced a deer with a straight arrow, he pursued it.

data.v: स मृगो बाणमादाय ययावमितविक्रमः । स च राजा बली तूर्णं ससार मृगमन्तिकात् ॥
data.md: Endued with great strength, the deer ran ahead, with the arrow sticking to him. The king was equally powerful, and accordingly pursued his precious game with great speed.

data.v: ततो निम्नं स्थलं चैव स मृगोऽद्रवदाशुगः । मुहूर्तमेव राजेन्द्र समेन स पथागमत् ॥
data.md: The animal, highly fleet, quickly ran a low ground and then a level plain.

data.v: ततः स राजा तारुण्यादौरसेन बलेन च । ससार बाणासनभृत्सखड्गो हंसवत्तदा ॥
data.md: The king, young, active, and strong, and armed with bow and sword and protected with a coat of mail, still pursued it.

data.v: तीर्त्वा नदान्नदीश्चैव पल्वलानि वनानि च । अतिक्रम्याभ्यतिक्रम्य ससारैव वने चरन् ॥
data.md: Having none with him to chase the animal through the forest, the king crossed many rivers and lakes.

data.v: स तु कामान्मृगो राजन्नासाद्यासाद्य तं नृपम् । पुनरभ्येति जवनो जवेन महता ततः ॥
data.md: Possessed of great fleetness the animal, at its will, appearing now and then before the king, ran on with great quickness.

data.v: स तस्य बाणैर्बहुभिः समभ्यस्तो वनेचरः । प्रक्रीडन्निव राजेन्द्र पुनरभ्येति चान्तिकम् ॥
data.md: Pierced with many arrows by the king, that wild animal, O monarch, as if in sport, again and again lessened the distance between itself and the pursuer.

data.v: पुनश्च जवमास्थाय जवनो मृगयूथपः । अतीत्यातीत्य राजेन्द्र पुनरभ्येति चान्तिकम् ॥
data.md: Repeatedly showing its quickness and crossing one forest after another, it now and then appeared before the king at a near point.

data.v: तस्य मर्मच्छिदं घोरं सुमित्रोऽमित्रकर्शनः । समादाय शरश्रेष्ठं कार्मुकान्निरवासृजत् ॥
data.md: At last, taking up a very excellent arrow, sharp, terrible, and capable of cutting the very vitals, the crusher of foes, set it on his bowstring.

data.v: ततो गव्यूतिमात्रेण मृगयूथपयूथपः । तस्य बाणपथं त्यक्त्वा तस्थिवान्प्रहसन्निव ॥
data.md: That huge animal then, as if laughing at the pursuer's efforts, suddenly went to a great distance by reaching a point full four miles ahead of the range of the arrow.

data.v: तस्मिन्निपतिते बाणे भूमौ प्रज्वलिते ततः । प्रविवेश महारण्यं मृगो राजाप्यथाद्रवत् ॥
data.md: That effulgent arrow accordingly fell on the ground. The deer entered a large forest, but the king still pursued it.

data.v: प्रविश्य तु महारण्यं तापसानामथाश्रमम् । आससाद ततो राजा श्रान्तश्चोपाविशत्पुनः ॥
data.md: Bhishma said Having entered that large forest, the king arrived at an asylum of ascetics. Worn out with toil, he sat himself down for rest.

data.v: तं कार्मुकधरं दृष्ट्वा श्रमार्तं क्षुधितं तदा । समेत्य ऋषयस्तस्मिन्पूजां चक्रुर्यथाविधि ॥
data.md: Seeing him armed with bow, exhausted with toil, and hungry, the ascetics approached him and honoured him duly.

data.v: ऋषयो राजशार्दूलमपृच्छन्स्वं प्रयोजनम् । केन भद्रमुखार्थेन संप्राप्तोऽसि तपोवनम् ॥
पदातिर्बद्धनिस्त्रिंशो धन्वी बाणी नरेश्वर । एतदिच्छाम विज्ञातुं कुतः प्राप्तोऽसि मानद । कस्मिन्कुले हि जातस्त्वं किंनामासि ब्रवीहि नः ॥
data.md: We wish to hear whence you are coming, O giver of honours! Tell us also in what family you are born and what your name is!-

data.v: ततः स राजा सर्वेभ्यो द्विजेभ्यः पुरुषर्षभ । आचख्यौ तद्यथान्यायं परिचर्यां च भारत ॥
