मृगस्तु विद्धो बाणेन मया सरति शल्यवान् । तं द्रवन्तमनु प्राप्तो वनमेतद्यदृच्छया । भवत्सकाशे नष्टश्रीर्हताशः श्रमकर्शितः ॥
data.md: In chasing it I have, purposelessly arrived at this forest and find myself before you, shorn of splendour, toil worn, and with hope disappointed.

data.v: किं नु दुःखमतोऽन्यद्वै यदहं श्रमकर्शितः । भवतामाश्रमं प्राप्तो हताशो नष्टलक्षणः ॥
data.md: What can be more pitiable than this, viz., that I have arrived at this hermitage, exhausted with toil, shorn of the signs of royalty, and disappointed of my hopes.

data.v: न राजलक्षणत्यागो न पुरस्य तपोधनाः । दुःखं करोति तत्तीव्रं यथाशा विहता मम ॥
data.md: I am not at all sorry, Oh ye ascetics, at my being now divested of the sins of royalty or at my being now at a distance from my capital. I feel, however, a great grief for my hopes being frustrated.

data.v: हिमवान्वा महाशैलः समुद्रो वा महोदधिः । महत्त्वान्नान्वपद्येतां रोदस्योरन्तरं यथा । आशायास्तपसि श्रेष्ठास्तथा नान्तमहं गतः ॥
data.md: The king of mountains, viz., Himavat, and that vast receptacle of waters, viz., the ocean, cannot, for its vastness, equal the extent of the sky.

data.v: भवतां विदितं सर्वं सर्वज्ञा हि तपोधनाः । भवन्तः सुमहाभागास्तस्मात्प्रक्ष्यामि संशयम् ॥
आशावान्पुरुषो यः स्यादन्तरिक्षमथापि वा । किं नु ज्यायस्तरं लोके महत्त्वात्प्रतिभाति वः । एतदिच्छामि तत्त्वेन श्रोतुं किमिह दुर्लभम् ॥
data.md: You are also highly blessed. I beg you, therefore, to remove my doubt. Which of these two appears vaster to you, hope of man, or the wide sky? I desire to hear fully, what is so unconquerable as hope.

data.v: यदि गुह्यं तपोनित्या न वो ब्रूतेह माचिरम् । न हि गुह्यमतः श्रोतुमिच्छामि द्विजपुंगवाः ॥
data.md: If the subject be one which you can properly describe, then tell me all about it forthwith. I do not wish, ye foremost of the twice-born, to hear anything from you be a mystery and improper to describe. that may

data.v: भवत्तपोविघातो वा येन स्याद्विरमे ततः । यदि वास्ति कथायोगो योऽयं प्रश्नो मयेरितः ॥
data.md: If again the subject be injurious to your penances, I would not wish you to describe. If the question asked by me be a befitting subject of discourse, I would then wish to hear the cause fully. Devoted to penances as ye are, do ye all instruct me on the subject.'

data.v: एतत्कारणसामग्र्यं श्रोतुमिच्छामि तत्त्वतः । भवन्तो हि तपोनित्या ब्रूयुरेतत्समाहिताः ॥
ततस्तेषां समस्तानामृषीणामृषिसत्तमः । ऋषभो नाम विप्रर्षिः स्मयन्निव ततोऽब्रवीत् ॥
data.md: Bhishma said Then the best of Rishis, viz., the twice-born Rishabha, sitting in the midst of all those Rishis, smiled a little and said

data.v: पुराहं राजशार्दूल तीर्थान्यनुचरन्प्रभो । समासादितवान्दिव्यं नरनारायणाश्रमम् ॥
data.md: Formerly, O foremost of Kings, while sojourning among sacred places, I arrived O lord, at the beautiful hermitage of Nara and Narayana.

data.v: यत्र सा बदरी रम्या ह्रदो वैहायसस्तथा । यत्र चाश्वशिरा राजन्वेदान्पठति शाश्वतान् ॥
data.md: There lies the charming spot called Badari, and there also is that lake in the sky. There the sage Ashvashiras, O king, reads the eternal Vedas.

data.v: तस्मिन्सरसि कृत्वाहं विधिवत्तर्पणं पुरा । पितॄणां देवतानां च ततोऽऽश्रममियां तदा ॥
data.md: Having performed my ablutions in that lake duly offered libations of water to the departed manes and the gods, I entered the hermitage.

data.v: रेमाते यत्र तौ नित्यं नरनारायणावृषी । अदूरादाश्रमं कंचिद्वासार्थमगमं ततः ॥
data.md: Within that retreat the Rishis Nara and Narayana always spend their time happily. Not far from that place I went to another hermitage for taking up my quarter.

data.v: ततश्चीराजिनधरं कृशमुच्चमतीव च । अद्राक्षमृषिमायान्तं तनुं नाम तपोनिधिम् ॥
data.md: While seated there I saw a very tall and emaciated Rishi, clad in rags and skins, coming towards me. Rich in penances, he was named Tanu,

data.v: अन्यैर्नरैर्महाबाहो वपुषाष्टगुणान्वितम् । कृशता चापि राजर्षे न दृष्टा तादृशी क्वचित् ॥
data.md: Compared, O mighty-armed one, with other men, his height was eight times greater. Regarding his leanness, O royal sage, I can say that I have never seen its like.

data.v: शरीरमपि राजेन्द्र तस्य कानिष्ठिकासमम् । ग्रीवा बाहू तथा पादौ केशाश्चाद्भुतदर्शनाः ॥
data.md: His body, O king, was as thin as one's little finger. His neck and arms and legs and hair were all of extraordinary character.

data.v: शिरः कायानुरूपं च कर्णौ नेत्रे तथैव च । तस्य वाक्चैव चेष्टा च सामान्ये राजसत्तम ॥
data.md: His head was proportionate to his body, and his ears and eyes, also, were the same. His speech, O best of kings, and his movements were highly feeble.

data.v: दृष्ट्वाहं तं कृशं विप्रं भीतः परमदुर्मनाः । पादौ तस्याभिवाद्याथ स्थितः प्राञ्जलिरग्रतः ॥
data.md: Seeing that highly emaciated Brahmana I became very dispirited and frightened. Saluting his feet, I stood before him with clasped hands.

data.v: निवेद्य नाम गोत्रं च पितरं च नरर्षभ । प्रदिष्टे चासने तेन शनैरहमुपाविशम् ॥
data.md: Having given out to him my name and family, and having told him also the name of my father, O foremost of men, I slowly sat myself down on a seat that was pointed out by him.

data.v: ततः स कथयामास कथा धर्मार्थसंहिताः । ऋषिमध्ये महाराज तत्र धर्मभृतां वरः ॥
data.md: Then, o king, that foremost of virtuous men, viz., Tanu, began to describe in the midst of the Rishis living in that hermitage the topics regarding Righteousness and Profit.

data.v: तस्मिंस्तु कथयत्येव राजा राजीवलोचनः । उपायाज्जवनैरश्वैः सबलः सावरोधनः ॥
data.md: While engaged in discourse, a king, having eyes like lotus-petals and accompanied by his forces and the ladies of his seraglio, came on a car drawn by quick-coursing horses.

data.v: स्मरन्पुत्रमरण्ये वै नष्टं परमदुर्मनाः । भूरिद्युम्नपिता धीमान्रघुश्रेष्ठो महायशाः ॥
data.md: The name of that king was Viradyumna. Of beautiful features, he was highly illustrious. His son's name was Bhuridyumna. The child has been missing, and the father, highly dispirited, came there in there in course of his wanderings amid the forest in pursuit of the missing one.

data.v: इह द्रक्ष्यामि तं पुत्रं द्रक्ष्यामीहेति पार्थिवः । एवमाशाकृतो राजंश्चरन्वनमिदं पुरा ॥
data.md: I shall find my son here!-I shall find my son here!-Carried on by hope in this way, the king wandered through that forest in those days.

data.v: दुर्लभः स मया द्रष्टुं नूनं परमधार्मिकः । एकः पुत्रो महारण्ये नष्ट इत्यसकृत्तदा ॥
data.md: Addressing the emaciated Rishi he said,-Forsooth, that highly virtuous son of mine cannot be traced by me. Alas, he was my only son. He is lost and can nowhere be found.

data.v: दुर्लभः स मया द्रष्टुमाशा च महती मम । तया परीतगात्रोऽहं मुमूर्षुर्नात्र संशयः ॥
data.md: Though he cannot be discovered my hope, however, of finding him is very great! With that hope (which is frequently disappointed) I am almost on the point of death.

data.v: एतच्छ्रुत्वा स भगवांस्तनुर्मुनिवरोत्तमः । अवाक्शिरा ध्यानपरो मुहूर्तमिव तस्थिवान् ॥
data.md: Hearing these words of the king, that foremost of ascetics, viz., the holy Tanu, remained for a short while with head lowering down and himself immersed in contemplation.

data.v: तमनुध्यान्तमालक्ष्य राजा परमदुर्मनाः । उवाच वाक्यं दीनात्मा मन्दं मन्दमिवासकृत् ॥
data.md: Seeing him immersed in contemplation, the king became highly disspirited. With great sorrow he began to say slowly and softly,-What, Ocelestial, Rishi, is that which cannot be conquered and what is it that is greater than hope? O holy one, tell me this if I may hear it without any objection.

data.v: दुर्लभं किं नु विप्रर्षे आशायाश्चैव किं भवेत् । ब्रवीतु भगवानेतद्यदि गुह्यं न तन्मयि ॥
महर्षिर्भगवांस्तेन पूर्वमासीद्विमानितः । बालिशां बुद्धिमास्थाय मन्दभाग्यतयात्मनः ॥
data.md: The ascetic said A holy and great ascetic had been insulted by your son. He had done it through ill luck, actuated by his foolish understanding.

data.v: अर्थयन्कलशं राजन्काञ्चनं वल्कलानि च । निर्विण्णः स तु विप्रर्षिर्निराशः समपद्यत ॥
data.md: The ascetic has asked your son for a golden jar and vegetable barks. Your son refused, out of contempt, to please the ascetic.

data.v: एवमुक्त्वाभिवाद्याथ तमृषिं लोकपूजितम् । श्रान्तो न्यषीदद्धर्मात्मा यथा त्वं नरसत्तम ॥
data.md: Thus treated by your son, the great sage became disappointed!-Thus addressed, the king adored that ascetic worshipped of all the world. Of virtuous soul, Viradyumna sat there, worn out with toil even as you, O best of men, noware.

data.v: अर्घ्यं ततः समानीय पाद्यं चैव महानृषिः । आरण्यकेन विधिना राज्ञे सर्वं न्यवेदयत् ॥
data.md: The great ascetic, in return, offered the dwellers, water to wash his feet and the Arghya.

data.v: ततस्ते मुनयः सर्वे परिवार्य नरर्षभम् । उपाविशन्पुरस्कृत्य सप्तर्षय इव ध्रुवम् ॥
data.md: Then all the ascetics, O. foremost of kings, sat there, encircling that foremost of men like the stars of the constellation of Ursa Major surrounding the Pole star.

data.v: अपृच्छंश्चैव ते तत्र राजानमपराजितम् । प्रयोजनमिदं सर्वमाश्रमस्य प्रवेशनम् ॥
data.md: And they asked the unvanquished king about the cause of his arrival at that hermitage.

data.v: वीरद्युम्न इति ख्यातो राजाहं दिक्षु विश्रुतः । भूरिद्युम्नं सुतं नष्टमन्वेष्टुं वनमागतः ॥
data.md: The king said I am a king named Viradyumna. My fame has travelled everywhere. My Bhuridyumna has been lost. To find him out I have come to this forest.

data.v: एकपुत्रः स विप्राग्र्य बाल एव च सोऽनघ । न दृश्यते वने चास्मिंस्तमन्वेष्टुं चराम्यहम् ॥
data.md: O ye foremost of Brahmanas, that child was my only son and, O ye of sinless ones, he is very young. He cannot, however, be found here. I am travelling everywhere for finding him out. son

data.v: एवमुक्ते तु वचने राज्ञा मुनिरधोमुखः । तूष्णीमेवाभवत्तत्र न च प्रत्युक्तवान्नृपम् ॥
data.md: Rishabha said After the king had said so, the ascetic Tanu lowered his head. He remained absolutely silent, without giving any response.

data.v: स हि तेन पुरा विप्रो राज्ञा नात्यर्थमानितः । आशाकृशं च राजेन्द्र तपो दीर्घं समास्थितः ॥
प्रतिग्रहमहं राज्ञां न करिष्ये कथंचन । अन्येषां चैव वर्णानामिति कृत्वा धियं तदा ॥
आशा हि पुरुषं बालं लालापयति तस्थुषी । तामहं व्यपनेष्यामि इति कृत्वा व्यवस्थितः ॥
आशायाः किं कृशत्वं च किं चेह भुवि दुर्लभम् । ब्रवीतु भगवानेतत्त्वं हि धर्मार्थदर्शिवान् ॥
data.md: What is the extent of the faintness of Hope? What on Earth is highly difficult to acquire? Tell me this, O holy one, for you are master of virtue and profit.

data.v: ततः संस्मृत्य तत्सर्वं स्मारयिष्यन्निवाब्रवीत् । राजानं भगवान्विप्रस्ततः कृशतनुस्तनुः ॥
data.md: Rishabha said Remembering all the past incidents and calling them back to the recollection of the king also, that holy Brahmana of emaciated body said to the king.

data.v: कृशत्वे न समं राजन्नाशाया विद्यते नृप । तस्या वै दुर्लभत्वात्तु प्रार्थिताः पार्थिवा मया ॥
data.md: The sage said-There is nothing, o king, which is so slender as Hope, I had requested many kings and found that there is nothing which is so The sage difficult of acquiring as an image presented by Hope before the mind!-

data.v: कृशाकृशे मया ब्रह्मन्गृहीते वचनात्तव । दुर्लभत्वं च तस्यैव वेदवाक्यमिव द्विज ॥
data.md: The king said At your words, O Brahmana, I understand what is feeble and what is not so. I understand also now difficult it is to acquire the images placed by hope before the mind. I consider these words of yours as Shruti.

data.v: संशयस्तु महाप्राज्ञ संजातो हृदये मम । तन्मे सत्तम तत्त्वेन वक्तुमर्हसि पृच्छतः ॥
data.md: O you of great wisdom, one doubt, however, is in my mind. You should, O sage, explain it fully to me.

data.v: त्वत्तः कृशतरं किं नु ब्रवीतु भगवानिदम् । यदि गुह्यं न ते विप्र लोकेऽस्मिन्किं नु दुर्लभम् ॥
data.md: What is slenderer than your body? Tell me this, O holy one, if, however, O best of sages, the subject is one, which may fairly be dealt with.

data.v: दुर्लभोऽप्यथ वा नास्ति योऽर्थी धृतिमिवाप्नुयात् । सुदुर्लभतरस्तात योऽर्थिनं नावमन्यते ॥
data.md: It highly difficult to find a contented applicant. Perhaps, there is none such in the world. Still rare, O sire, is the man who never disregards an applicant.

data.v: संश्रुत्य नोपक्रियते परं शक्त्या यथार्हतः । सक्ता या सर्वभूतेषु साशा कृशतरी मया ॥
data.md: The hope in persons who do not, after making promises, do good to others, to the best of their abilities and according to the fitness of the applicant, is slenderer than even my body.

data.v: एकपुत्रः पिता पुत्रे नष्टे वा प्रोषिते तथा । प्रवृत्तिं यो न जानाति साशा कृशतरी मया ॥
data.md: The hope entertained by a father who has only one son, of once more seeing him after he has been lost or missed, is slenderer than even my body.

data.v: प्रसवे चैव नारीणां वृद्धानां पुत्रकारिता । तथा नरेन्द्र धनिनामाशा कृशतरी मया ॥
data.md: The hope that old women hold of giving birth to sons, O king, and which is cherished by rich men, is slenderer than even my body.

data.v: एतच्छ्रुत्वा ततो राजन्स राजा सावरोधनः । संस्पृश्य पादौ शिरसा निपपात द्विजर्षभे ॥
data.md: Hearing these words, O monarch, king Viradyumna, and the ladies of his household, laid themselves low before that foremost of Brahmanas and touched his feet with their bent heads.

data.v: प्रसादये त्वा भगवन्पुत्रेणेच्छामि संगतिम् । वृणीष्व च वरं विप्र यमिच्छसि यथाविधि ॥
अब्रवीच्च हि तं वाक्यं राजा राजीवलोचनः । सत्यमेतद्यथा विप्र त्वयोक्तं नास्त्यतो मृषा ॥
ततः प्रहस्य भगवांस्तनुर्धर्मभृतां वरः । पुत्रमस्यानयत्क्षिप्रं तपसा च श्रुतेन च ॥
तं समानाय्य पुत्रं तु तदोपालभ्य पार्थिवम् । आत्मानं दर्शयामास धर्मं धर्मभृतां वरः ॥
संदर्शयित्वा चात्मानं दिव्यमद्भुतदर्शनम् । विपाप्मा विगतक्रोधश्चचार वनमन्तिकात् ॥
data.md: Indeed, having shown his own wonderful and celestials form, he entered an adjacent forest, with heart shorn of anger and the desire of revenge.

data.v: एतद्दृष्टं मया राजंस्ततश्च वचनं श्रुतम् । आशामपनयस्वाशु ततः कृशतरीमिमाम् ॥
data.md: I saw all this, O king, and heard the words I have said. Dispell your hope that is even slenderer than any of those which the sage pointed out.

data.v: स तत्रोक्तो महाराज ऋषभेण महात्मना । सुमित्रोऽपनयत्क्षिप्रमाशां कृशतरीं तदा ॥
data.md: Bhishma said Thus addressed, O king, by the great Rishabha, king Sumitra quickly renounced the hope that was in his heart and which was slenderer than any of the various sorts of hope pointed out by the emaciated Rishi.

data.v: एवं त्वमपि कौन्तेय श्रुत्वा वाणीमिमां मम । स्थिरो भव यथा राजन्हिमवानचलोत्तमः ॥
data.md: Do you also, O son of Kunti, hearing these words of mine, be calm and composed like Himavat.

data.v: त्वं हि द्रष्टा च श्रोता च कृच्छ्रेष्वर्थकृतेष्विह । श्रुत्वा मम महाराज न संतप्तुमिहार्हसि ॥
data.md: Stricken with distress you have questioned me and heard my answer. Fiaving heard it, O monarch, you should remove these regrets of yours.

data.v: नामृतस्येव पर्याप्तिर्ममास्ति ब्रुवति त्वयि । तस्मात्कथय भूयस्त्वं धर्ममेव पितामह ॥
अत्राप्युदाहरन्तीममितिहासं पुरातनम् । गौतमस्य च संवादं यमस्य च महात्मनः ॥
data.md: Bhishma said-Regarding it is cited the old story of the discourse between the Ocean and the Rivers.

data.v: पारियात्रगिरिं प्राप्य गौतमस्याश्रमो महान् । उवास गौतमो यत्र कालं तदपि मे शृणु ॥
data.md: Gotama had a wide retrert on the Paripatra hills. Listen to me as to how many years he lived in that asylum. For sixty thousand years that sage practises ascetic austerities in that asylum.

data.v: षष्टिं वर्षसहस्राणि सोऽतप्यद्गौतमस्तपः । तमुग्रतपसं युक्तं तपसा भावितं मुनिम् ॥
उपयातो नरव्याघ्र लोकपालो यमस्तदा । तमपश्यत्सुतपसमृषिं वै गौतमं मुनिम् ॥
data.md: One day, the Regent of the dead. Yama, O foremost of men, went to that great sage of purified soul while he was practising the severest austerities. Yama saw the great ascetic Gotama of rigid penances.

data.v: स तं विदित्वा ब्रह्मर्षिर्यममागतमोजसा । प्राञ्जलिः प्रयतो भूत्वा उपसृप्तस्तपोधनः ॥
data.md: Understanding that it was Yama who had come, the twice-born quickly saluted him and sat with closed hands in an attentive attitude,

data.v: तं धर्मराजो दृष्ट्वैव नमस्कृत्य नरर्षभम् । न्यमन्त्रयत धर्मेण क्रियतां किमिति ब्रुवन् ॥
data.md: Beholding that foremost of Brahmanas, the royal Dharma duly saluted him and addressing him asked what he should do for him.

data.v: मातापितृभ्यामानृण्यं किं कृत्वा समवाप्नुयात् । कथं च लोकानश्नाति पुरुषो दुर्लभाञ्शुभान् ॥
data.md: Gotama said How does a man liberate his self from the debt he owes to his parents? How, also, does he succeed in acquiring blissful regions which it is so difficult to acquire.

data.v: तपःशौचवता नित्यं सत्यधर्मरतेन च । मातापित्रोरहरहः पूजनं कार्यमञ्जसा ॥
data.md: Yama said Practising truth, purity and penances, one should continuously adore his parents.

data.v: अश्वमेधैश्च यष्टव्यं बहुभिः स्वाप्तदक्षिणैः । तेन लोकानुपाश्नाति पुरुषोऽद्भुतदर्शनान् ॥
data.md: One should, also, celebrate Horse-sacrifices with profuse presents to the Brahmanas. By such acts one acquires many happy and wonderful regions.'

data.v: मित्रैः प्रहीयमाणस्य बह्वमित्रस्य का गतिः । राज्ञः संक्षीणकोशस्य बलहीनस्य भारत ॥
data.md: Yudhishthira said How should a king behave who is shorn of friends, has many enemies, and an exhausted treasury, and is destitute of troops, O Bharata.

data.v: दुष्टामात्यसहायस्य स्रुतमन्त्रस्य सर्वतः । राज्यात्प्रच्यवमानस्य गतिमन्यामपश्यतः ॥
परचक्राभियातस्य दुर्बलस्य बलीयसा । असंविहितराष्ट्रस्य देशकालावजानतः ॥
अप्राप्यं च भवेत्सान्त्वं भेदो वाप्यतिपीडनात् । जीवितं चार्थहेतोर्वा तत्र किं सुकृतं भवेत् ॥
गुह्यं मा धर्ममप्राक्षीरतीव भरतर्षभ । अपृष्टो नोत्सहे वक्तुं धर्ममेनं युधिष्ठिर ॥
धर्मो ह्यणीयान्वचनाद्बुद्धेश्च भरतर्षभ । श्रुत्वोपास्य सदाचारैः साधुर्भवति स क्वचित् ॥
data.md: Bhishma said Conversant as you are with duties, you have, O foremost of Bharata's race, asked me a question dealing with the mystery of duties. Without being asked, O Yudhishthira, I could not venture to dwell upon this duty. Morality is very subtile. One understands it, О foremost of Bharata's race by the help of scriptural texts. By remembering what one has heard and by doing good acts, some one in some place may become a righteous person.

data.v: कर्मणा बुद्धिपूर्वेण भवत्याढ्यो न वा पुनः । तादृशोऽयमनुप्रश्नः स व्यवस्यस्त्वया धिया ॥
data.md: By acting intelligently the king may or may not acquire wealth. Guided by your own intelligence do you think what reply should be given to your query on this subject.

data.v: उपायं धर्मबहुलं यात्रार्थं शृणु भारत । नाहमेतादृशं धर्मं बुभूषे धर्मकारणात् । दुःखादान इहाढ्येषु स्यात्तु पश्चात्क्षमो मतः ॥
data.md: Listen, O Bharata, to the highly meritorious expedient which kings should follow (during times of distress). For the sake of true morality, however, I would not call those means fair.

data.v: अनुगम्य गतीनां च सर्वासामेव निश्चयम् । यथा यथा हि पुरुषो नित्यं शास्त्रमवेक्षते । तथा तथा विजानाति विज्ञानं चास्य रोचते ॥
data.md: The scriptures or science which one always studies imparts him the knowledge becomes agreeable to him.

data.v: अविज्ञानादयोगश्च पुरुषस्योपजायते । अविज्ञानादयोगो हि योगो भूतिकरः पुनः ॥
data.md: Ignorance yields barrenness of invention about means. Finding out of expedicnts, again, through the help of knowledge, becomes the source of great happiness. Without cherishing any misgivings and any malice, here these instructions.

data.v: अशङ्कमानो वचनमनसूयुरिदं शृणु । राज्ञः कोशक्षयादेव जायते बलसंक्षयः ॥
कोशं संजनयेद्राजा निर्जलेभ्यो यथा जलम् । कालं प्राप्यानुगृह्णीयादेष धर्मोऽत्र सांप्रतम् ॥
उपायधर्मं प्राप्यैनं पूर्वैराचरितं जनैः । अन्यो धर्मः समर्थानामापत्स्वन्यश्च भारत ॥
प्राक्कोशः प्रोच्यते धर्मो बुद्धिर्धर्माद्गरीयसी । धर्मं प्राप्य न्यायवृत्तिमबलीयान्न विन्दति ॥
यस्माद्धनस्योपपत्तिरेकान्तेन न विद्यते । तस्मादापद्यधर्मोऽपि श्रूयते धर्मलक्षणः ॥
अधर्मो जायते यस्मिन्निति वै कवयो विदुः । अनन्तरः क्षत्रियस्य इति वै विचिकित्ससे ॥
यथास्य धर्मो न ग्लायेन्नेयाच्छत्रुवशं यथा । तत्कर्तव्यमिहेत्याहुर्नात्मानमवसादयेत् ॥
data.md: After the time of distress is over, what should the Kshatriya do? He should act in such a way that his merit may not be dissipated. He should also act in such a way that he may not have to yield to his foes. These are his duties. He should not be despondent.

data.v: सन्नात्मा नैव धर्मस्य न परस्य न चात्मनः । सर्वोपायैरुज्जिहीर्षेदात्मानमिति निश्चयः ॥
data.md: He should not try to save the merit of others or of himself. On the other hand, he should save his own self. This is the settled conclusion. There runs this Shruti, viz., that Brahmanas, who are conversant with duties, should be proficient in them. Likewise, as regards the Kshatriya, his proficiency should be in exertion, since might of arms is his great wealth.

data.v: तत्र धर्मविदां तात निश्चयो धर्मनैपुणे । उद्यमो जीवनं क्षत्रे बाहुवीर्यादिति श्रुतिः ॥
data.md: He should not try to save the merit of others or of himself. On the other hand, he should save his own self. This is the settled conclusion. There runs this Shruti, viz., that Brahmanas, who are conversant with duties, should be proficient in them. Likewise, as regards the Kshatriya, his proficiency should be in exertion, since might of arms is his great wealth.

data.v: क्षत्रियो वृत्तिसंरोधे कस्य नादातुमर्हति । अन्यत्र तापसस्वाच्च ब्राह्मणस्वाच्च भारत ॥
data.md: When a Kshatriya's means of sustenance are gone, what should he not take excepting what belongs to ascetics and Brahmanas?

data.v: यथा वै ब्राह्मणः सीदन्नयाज्यमपि याजयेत् । अभोज्यान्नानि चाश्नीयात्तथेदं नात्र संशयः ॥
data.md: Even as a Brahmana in a time of distress may officiate at the sacrifice of a person for whom he should never officiate and eat forbidden food, so there is no doubt that a Kshatriya may take riches from every one say ascetics and Brahmanas.

data.v: पीडितस्य किमद्वारमुत्पथो निधृतस्य वा । अद्वारतः प्रद्रवति यदा भवति पीडितः ॥
data.md: Even one attacked (by an enemy and seeking the means of escape) what can be an unfair means? For a person confined in a ungeon and seeking escape what can be an improper path? When a person becomes afflicted, he escapes by even an improper way.

data.v: तस्य कोशबलज्यान्या सर्वलोकपराभवः । भैक्षचर्या न विहिता न च विट्शूद्रजीविका ॥
data.md: For a Kshatriya who has, for his insufficient treasury and army, become exceedingly humiliated, neither a life of mendicancy nor the profession of a Vaishya or that of a Shudra has been sanctioned.

data.v: स्वधर्मानन्तरा वृत्तिर्यान्याननुपजीवतः । वहतः प्रथमं कल्पमनुकल्पेन जीवनम् ॥
data.md: The profession prescribed for a Kshatriya is the acquisition of wealth by battle and victory. He should never beg of a member of his own caste. The person who maintains himself ordinarily by following the practices primarily sanctioned, for him, may, in times of distress, support himself by following the practices laid down in the alternative.

data.v: आपद्गतेन धर्माणामन्यायेनोपजीवनम् । अपि ह्येतद्ब्राह्मणेषु दृष्टं वृत्तिपरिक्षये ॥
data.md: In a time of distress, when ordinary practices cannot be followed, a Kshatriya may support himself by even unjust and improper means. The very Brahmanas, it is seen, do the same when their means of living run out.

data.v: क्षत्रिये संशयः कः स्यादित्येतन्निश्चितं सदा । आददीत विशिष्टेभ्यो नावसीदेत्कथंचन ॥
हन्तारं रक्षितारं च प्रजानां क्षत्रियं विदुः । तस्मात्संरक्षता कार्यमादानं क्षत्रबन्धुना ॥
data.md: When the Brahmanas act thus, what doubt is there regarding the conduct of the Kshatriya)? This is, indeed, settled. Without despairing and yielding to destruction, a Kshatriya nay, by force, take, what he can, from rich persons. Know that the Kshatriya may, by force, take, what he can, from rich persons. Know that the Kshatriya is the protector and the destroyer of the people. Therefore, a Kshatriya in difficulty should take by force, what he can, with a view to protect the people.

data.v: अन्यत्र राजन्हिंसाया वृत्तिर्नेहास्ति कस्यचित् । अप्यरण्यसमुत्थस्य एकस्य चरतो मुनेः ॥
data.md: No person in this world, O king, can maintain himself without injuring other creatures. The very ascetic leading a solitary life in the forest is no exception.

data.v: न शङ्खलिखितां वृत्तिं शक्यमास्थाय जीवितुम् । विशेषतः कुरुश्रेष्ठ प्रजापालनमीप्सता ॥
data.md: A Kshatriya should not live, depending upon destiny, especially he, O chief of the Kurus, who wishes to rule.

data.v: परस्पराभिसंरक्षा राज्ञा राष्ट्रेण चापदि । नित्यमेवेह कर्तव्या एष धर्मः सनातनः ॥
data.md: The king and the kingdom should always mutually protect each other. This is an eternal duty.

data.v: राजा राष्ट्रं यथापत्सु द्रव्यौघैः परिरक्षति । राष्ट्रेण राजा व्यसने परिरक्ष्यस्तथा भवेत् ॥
data.md: As the king protects, by spending all his money, the kingdom, when it is in distress, so should the kingdom protect the kingdom protect the king when he is in distress.

data.v: कोशं दण्डं बलं मित्रं यदन्यदपि संचितम् । न कुर्वीतान्तरं राष्ट्रे राजा परिगते क्षुधा ॥
data.md: The king, even when reduced to straits, should never abandon his treasury, his machinery for punishing the wicked, his army, his friends and allies, and uther necessary institutions and the chiefs living in his kingdom.

data.v: बीजं भक्तेन संपाद्यमिति धर्मविदो विदुः । अत्रैतच्छम्बरस्याहुर्महामायस्य दर्शनम् ॥
data.md: Masters of duty say that one must keep his seeds, even from his very food. This a truth cited from the work of Shamvara, well-known for his great powers of illusion.

data.v: धिक्तस्य जीवितं राज्ञो राष्ट्रे यस्यावसीदति । अवृत्त्यान्त्यमनुष्योऽपि यो वै वेद शिबेर्वचः ॥
data.md: Fie on the life of that king whose kingdom is weakened. Fie on the life of that men who from want of means goes to a foreign country in quest of a living.

data.v: राज्ञः कोशबलं मूलं कोशमूलं पुनर्बलम् । तन्मूलं सर्वधर्माणां धर्ममूलाः पुनः प्रजाः ॥
data.md: The king depends upon his treasury and army. His army, again, depends on his treasury. His army is the source of all his religious merits. His religious merits, again, are the root of his people.

data.v: नान्यानपीडयित्वेह कोशः शक्यः कुतो बलम् । तदर्थं पीडयित्वा च दोषं न प्राप्तुमर्हति ॥
data.md: The treasury can never be replenished without oppressing others. How then can the army be maintained without oppression? The king, therefore, in times of difficulty, commits no sin by oppressing his subjects for filling the treasury.

data.v: अकार्यमपि यज्ञार्थं क्रियते यज्ञकर्मसु । एतस्मात्कारणाद्राजा न दोषं प्राप्तुमर्हति ॥
data.md: For celebrating sacrifices many improper deeds are done. Therefore a king commits no sin by doing improper acts (when he seeks to fill his treasury in a time of distress).

data.v: अर्थार्थमन्यद्भवति विपरीतमथापरम् । अनर्थार्थमथाप्यन्यत्तत्सर्वं ह्यर्थलक्षणम् । एवं बुद्ध्या संप्रपश्येन्मेधावी कार्यनिश्चयम् ॥
data.md: Virtue is not always the root of Profit, for other things then Virtue lead to Wealth. There is again the opposite view. In some cases, Wealth acquired has produced evil. Other things again than Wealth have brought on the acquisition of Virtue. Therefore, an ignorant man, whose understanding has been debased by ignorance, never succeeds in acquiring the highest object of Virtue and Profit, viz., Emancipation.

data.v: यज्ञार्थमन्यद्भवति यज्ञे नार्थस्तथापरः । यज्ञस्यार्थार्थमेवान्यत्तत्सर्वं यज्ञसाधनम् ॥
data.md: As animals and other articles are a necessary or sacrifices, as sacrifices are for purifying the heart, and as animals, sacrifices, and purity of the heart, are all for final liberation, even so policy and punishment exist for the treasury, the treasury, exists for the army, and policy and treasury and army all the three exists for defeating enemies and protecting or enlarging the kingdom.

data.v: उपमामत्र वक्ष्यामि धर्मतत्त्वप्रकाशिनीम् । यूपं छिन्दन्ति यज्ञार्थं तत्र ये परिपन्थिनः ॥
data.md: I shall here quote an example illustrating the true way of morality. A large tree is cut down for making out of it a sacrificial stake. In cutting it, other trees which stand in its way have also to be cut down. These, also, while falling down, kill others standing there about.

data.v: द्रुमाः केचन सामन्ता ध्रुवं छिन्दन्ति तानपि । ते चापि निपतन्तोऽन्यान्निघ्नन्ति च वनस्पतीन् ॥
एवं कोशस्य महतो ये नराः परिपन्थिनः । तानहत्वा न पश्यामि सिद्धिमत्र परंतप ॥
data.md: So they who stand in the way of replenishing a treasury must be killed. I do not see how else success can be acquired.

data.v: धनेन जयते लोकावुभौ परमिमं तथा । सत्यं च धर्मवचनं यथा नास्त्यधनस्तथा ॥
data.md: By wealth, both the worlds, viz., this and the other, can be acquired, as also Truth and religious merit. A person who has no wealth is more dead than alive.

data.v: सर्वोपायैराददीत धनं यज्ञप्रयोजनम् । न तुल्यदोषः स्यादेवं कार्याकार्येषु भारत ॥
data.md: Wealth for the celebration of sacrifices should be won by every means. The demerit of an act, done in an hour of difficulty, does not equal to that which permeates the same, if done at other tinies, O Bharata.

data.v: नैतौ संभवतो राजन्कथंचिदपि भारत । न ह्यरण्येषु पश्यामि धनवृद्धानहं क्वचित् ॥
data.md: The acquisition of wealth and its abandonment cannot both be possibly suen in the same individual, O king. I do not see a rich man in the forest.

data.v: यदिदं दृश्यते वित्तं पृथिव्यामिह किंचन । ममेदं स्यान्ममेदं स्यादित्ययं काङ्क्षते जनः ॥
data.md: With respect to wealth which is seen in this world, every one fights with every one else, saying,-This shall be mine.-This shall be imine.

data.v: न च राज्यसमो धर्मः कश्चिदस्ति परंतप । धर्मं शंसन्ति ते राज्ञामापदर्थमितोऽन्यथा ॥
data.md: There is nothing, O scorcher of foes, which yields greater merit to a king than the possession of a kingdom. It is sinful for a king to oppress his subjects with heavy taxes at ordinary times. In a season of distress, it is quite different.

data.v: दानेन कर्मणा चान्ये तपसान्ये तपस्विनः । बुद्ध्या दाक्ष्येण चाप्यन्ये चिन्वन्ति धनसंचयान् ॥
data.md: Some acquire wealth by gifts and sacrifices; some who like penances acquire the same by penances; some acquire it by the help of their intelligence and cleverness.

data.v: अधनं दुर्बलं प्राहुर्धनेन बलवान्भवेत् । सर्वं धनवतः प्राप्यं सर्वं तरति कोशवान् । कोशाद्धर्मश्च कामश्च परो लोकस्तथाप्ययम् ॥
data.md: A person who has no wealth is said to be weak, while he who has wealth becomes powerful. A man of riches may acquire everything. A king who has a well-replenished treasury can accomplish everything.

data.v: क्षीणस्य दीर्घसूत्रस्य सानुक्रोशस्य बन्धुषु । विरक्तपौरराष्ट्रस्य निर्द्रव्यनिचयस्य च ॥
परिशङ्कितमुख्यस्य स्रुतमन्त्रस्य भारत । असंभावितमित्रस्य भिन्नामात्यस्य सर्वशः ॥
परचक्राभियातस्य दुर्बलस्य बलीयसा । आपन्नचेतसो ब्रूहि किं कार्यमवशिष्यते ॥
data.md: What, indeed, should that king do whose cities and kingdoms have been divided and appropriated by enemies, who is divested of wealth, who cannot honour his friends and win them over to himself, whose ministers are disunited or brought over by his enemies, who is obliged to stand in the face of enemies, whose army has been diminished, and whose heart has been agitated by some strong enemy?

data.v: बाह्यश्चेद्विजिगीषुः स्याद्धर्मार्थकुशलः शुचिः । जवेन संधिं कुर्वीत पूर्वान्पूर्वान्विमोक्षयन् ॥
data.md: If the attacking enemy be of pure heart and if he be a master of both virtue and profit, a king of the sort you have pointed out, should forthwith, make peace with the invader and secure the restoration of those parts of the kingdom which have already been conquered.

data.v: अधर्मविजिगीषुश्चेद्बलवान्पापनिश्चयः । आत्मनः संनिरोधेन संधिं तेनाभियोजयेत् ॥
data.md: If, again, the invader be powerful and iniquitious and seek to acquire victory by unfair means, the king should inake peace with him, too, by leaving off a portion of his kingdom.

data.v: अपास्य राजधानीं वा तरेदन्येन वापदम् । तद्भावभावे द्रव्याणि जीवन्पुनरुपार्जयेत् ॥
data.md: If the invader be reluctant to make peace, the king should then leave his very capital and all his properties for escaping from danger. If he can save his life he may expect to make similar acquisitions in future.

data.v: यास्तु स्युः केवलत्यागाच्छक्यास्तरितुमापदः । कस्तत्राधिकमात्मानं संत्यजेदर्थधर्मवित् ॥
data.md: What man who knows virtue is there, who would sacrifice his own self, which is a more valuable property, for meeting that danger from which he can escape by abandoning his treasury and army?

data.v: अवरोधाज्जुगुप्सेत का सपत्नधने दया । न त्वेवात्मा प्रदातव्यः शक्ये सति कथंचन ॥
data.md: A king should protect the ladies of his seraglio. If these fall into the hands to the enemy, he should not show any mercy. As long as he can, he should never surrender his own self to the enemy.

data.v: आभ्यन्तरे प्रकुपिते बाह्ये चोपनिपीडिते । क्षीणे कोशे स्रुते मन्त्रे किं कार्यमवशिष्यते ॥
data.md: What should a king do when his own people are dissatisfied with him, when he is oppressed by invaders, when his treasury is exhausted and when his counsels are given out?

data.v: क्षिप्रं वा संधिकामः स्यात्क्षिप्रं वा तीक्ष्णविक्रमः । पदापनयनं क्षिप्रमेतावत्सांपरायिकम् ॥
data.md: Bhishma said: A king, under such circumstances, should (if his enemy be righteous) try to make peace with him. If the enemy be vicious, he should then display his courage. He should by such means, try to cause the enemy to retire from his kingdom; or, fighting bravely, he should sacrifice his life and ascend to heaven.

data.v: अनुरक्तेन पुष्टेन हृष्टेन जगतीपते । अल्पेनापि हि सैन्येन महीं जयति पार्थिवः ॥
data.md: A king can conquer the whole Earth with the help of even a small army if that army be loyal, contented, and devoted to his well-being.

data.v: हतो वा दिवमारोहेद्विजयी क्षितिमावसेत् । युद्धे तु संत्यजन्प्राणाञ्शक्रस्यैति सलोकताम् ॥
data.md: If killed in battle, he is sure to ascend to heaven. If he succeed in killing (his enemies), he is sure to enjoy the Earth. By sacrificing one's life in battle, one lives with Indra himself.'

data.v: सर्वलोकागमं कृत्वा मृदुत्वं गन्तुमेव च । विश्वासाद्विनयं कुर्याद्व्यवस्येद्वाप्युपानहौ ॥
data.md: Pleasing all people of opposition taking them in trust with humble, king should search other means to regain previous ones.

data.v: अपक्रमितुमिच्छेद्वा यथाकामं तु सान्त्वयेत् । विलिङ्गमित्वा मित्रेण ततः स्वयमुपक्रमेत् ॥
data.md: Or by the sweetest words he should please them by means of conciliation and again by the consultation with wise men he should act to regain it.

data.v: हीने परमके धर्मे सर्वलोकातिलङ्घिनि । सर्वस्मिन्दस्युसाद्भूते पृथिव्यामुपजीवने ॥
केनास्मिन्ब्राह्मणो जीवेज्जघन्ये काल आगते । असंत्यजन्पुत्रपौत्राननुक्रोशात्पितामह ॥
data.md: Yudhishthira said When virtuous practices calculated to be beneficial the worlds, disappear, when all the means and resources for subsistence fall into the hands of robbers, when such a calamitous time appears, by what means should a Brahmana, O grandfather, who from affection cannot leave his sons and grandsons maintain himself?

data.v: विज्ञानबलमास्थाय जीवितव्यं तथागते । सर्वं साध्वर्थमेवेदमसाध्वर्थं न किंचन ॥
data.md: Bhishma said When such a time appears the Brahmana should live by the help of knowledge. Everything in this world is for the good. Nothing here is for the wicked.

data.v: असाधुभ्यो निरादाय साधुभ्यो यः प्रयच्छति । आत्मानं संक्रमं कृत्वा कृत्स्नधर्मविदेव सः ॥
data.md: He, who, himself being an instrument of acquisition, takes wealth from the wicked and gives it to the good, is said to be conversant with the virtue of adversity.

data.v: सुरोषेणात्मनो राजन्राज्ये स्थितिमकोपयन् । अदत्तमप्याददीत दातुर्वित्तं ममेति वा ॥
data.md: Desirous of preserving his rule, the king, O monarch, without making his subjects indignant and rebellious may take what is not given to him by the owner, of his own accord, saying,-This is mine.

data.v: विज्ञानबलपूतो यो वर्तते निन्दितेष्वपि । वृत्तविज्ञानवान्धीरः कस्तं किं वक्तुमर्हति ॥
data.md: That wise man, who, purified by the possession of knowledge, power and righteous conduct at other times, acts censurably in such times, does not really deserve to be blamed.

data.v: येषां बलकृता वृत्तिर्नैषामन्याभिरोचते । तेजसाभिप्रवर्धन्ते बलवन्तो युधिष्ठिर ॥
data.md: They, who always support themselves by displaying their power, never prefer any other mode of living. The powerful, O Yudhishthira, always live by the help of prowess.

data.v: यदेव प्रकृतं शास्त्रमविशेषेण विन्दति । तदेव मध्याः सेवन्ते मेधावी चाप्यथोत्तरम् ॥
data.md: The ordinary injunctions of the scriptures, without exceptions of any kind, should be followed by a king at such times, while following those scriptures, an intelligent king would do something more.

data.v: ऋत्विक्पुरोहिताचार्यान्सत्कृतैरभिपूजितान् । न ब्राह्मणान्यातयेत दोषान्प्राप्नोति यातयन् ॥
data.md: At such times, however, the king should not oppress Ritwijas, Purohitas preceptors and Brahmanas, all of whom are respected and held in high esteem. By oppressing them, even at such times, he incurs blame and sin.

data.v: एतत्प्रमाणं लोकस्य चक्षुरेतत्सनातनम् । तत्प्रमाणोऽवगाहेत तेन तत्साध्वसाधु वा ॥
data.md: This is considered as an authority in the world. Indeed, this is the eternal eye. One should be guided by this authority. This determines whether a king is to be called good or wicked.

data.v: बहूनि ग्रामवास्तव्या रोषाद्ब्रूयुः परस्परम् । न तेषां वचनाद्राजा सत्कुर्याद्यातयेत वा ॥
data.md: It is seen that moved by jealousy and anger many persons, living in villages and towns, vilify one another. The king should never, as said by them, honour or punish any body.

data.v: न वाच्यः परिवादो वै न श्रोतव्यः कथंचन । कर्णावेव पिधातव्यौ प्रस्थेयं वा ततोऽन्यतः ॥

data.md: None of you should ever kill a woman amongst all creatures. Let Brahmanas be always blessed and you should always fight for their well-being.

data.v: सस्यं च नापहन्तव्यं सीरविघ्नं च मा कृथाः । पूज्यन्ते यत्र देवाश्च पितरोऽतिथयस्तथा ॥
data.md: You should never sacrifice truth. You should never obstruct the marriages of men. You should never injure those houses in which the deities, the Pitris, and guests and adored.

data.v: सर्वभूतेष्वपि च वै ब्राह्मणो मोक्षमर्हति । कार्या चापचितिस्तेषां सर्वस्वेनापि या भवेत् ॥
data.md: Amongst creatures, Brahmanas should always be exempted by you in your plunders. By giving away everything you have you should adore them.

data.v: यस्य ह्येते संप्ररुष्टा मन्त्रयन्ति पराभवम् । न तस्य त्रिषु लोकेषु त्राता भवति कश्चन ॥
data.md: He, who incurs the anger of the Brahmanas, he, whose discomfiture they seek, cannot find a rescuer in the three worlds.

data.v: यो ब्राह्मणान्परिभवेद्विनाशं वापि रोचयेत् । सूर्योदय इवावश्यं ध्रुवं तस्य पराभवः ॥
data.md: He, who vilifies the Brahmanas and wishes for their destruction, is himself ruined like darkness at sunrise.

data.v: इहैव फलमासीनः प्रत्याकाङ्क्षति शक्तितः । ये ये नो न प्रदास्यन्ति तांस्तान्सेनाभियास्यति ॥
data.md: Living here, you shall acquire the fruits of your valour. Troops will be sent against those who will refuse to give us our dues.

data.v: शिष्ट्यर्थं विहितो दण्डो न वधार्थं विनिश्चयः । ये च शिष्टान्प्रबाधन्ते धर्मस्तेषां वधः स्मृतः ॥
data.md: The rod of punishment is intended for the wicked. It is not intended for self-seeking. They who oppress the good should be killed.

data.v: ये हि राष्ट्रोपरोधेन वृत्तिं कुर्वन्ति केचन । तदेव तेऽनु मीयन्ते कुणपं कृमयो यथा ॥
data.md: They who seek to multiply their fortunes by afflicting kingdoms unscrupulously, are as vermins in a dead body.

data.v: ये पुनर्धर्मशास्त्रेण वर्तेरन्निह दस्यवः । अपि ते दस्यवो भूत्वा क्षिप्रं सिद्धिमवाप्नुयुः ॥
data.md: Those robbers, again, who would follow the restraints of the scriptures, would soon acquire salvation although leading a plundering life.

data.v: तत्सर्वमुपचक्रुस्ते कापव्यस्यानुशासनम् । वृत्तिं च लेभिरे सर्वे पापेभ्यश्चाप्युपारमन् ॥
data.md: Bhishma said Thus addressed, those robbers obeyed all the commands of Kayavya. By desisting from sin, they acquired great prosperity.

data.v: कापव्यः कर्मणा तेन महतीं सिद्धिमाप्तवान् । साधूनामाचरन्क्षेमं दस्यून्पापान्निवर्तयन् ॥
data.md: By behaving thus, by thus doing good to the honest and by thus restraining the robbers from bad practices, Kayavya acquired great success (in the next world).

data.v: इदं कापव्यचरितं यो नित्यमनुकीर्तयेत् । नारण्येभ्यः स भूतेभ्यो भयमार्छेत्कदाचन ॥
data.md: He, who always meditates on this narrative of Kayavya will have no fear from the forestrangers, in fact, from any earthly creature.

data.v: भयं तस्य न मर्त्येभ्यो नामर्त्येभ्यः कथंचन । न सतो नासतो राजन्स ह्यरण्येषु गोपतिः ॥
अत्र गाथा ब्रह्मगीताः कीर्तयन्ति पुराविदः । येन मार्गेण राजानः कोशं संजनयन्ति च ॥
data.md: Bhishma said Regarding the way in which a king should fill his treasury, persons will read in the scriptures of olden days, cite the following verses sung by Brahmana himself.

data.v: न धनं यज्ञशीलानां हार्यं देवस्वमेव तत् । दस्यूनां निष्क्रियाणां च क्षत्रियो हर्तुमर्हति ॥
data.md: The wealth of persons who celebrate sacrifices, as also the wealth dedicated to the deities, should never be taken. A Kshatriya should take the wealth of such persons as never perform religious rites and sacrifices, and who are, therefore, considered to be equal to robbers.

data.v: इमाः प्रजाः क्षत्रियाणां रक्ष्याश्चाद्याश्च भारत । धनं हि क्षत्रियस्येह द्वितीयस्य न विद्यते ॥
data.md: All the creatures of the Earth and all the enjoyments of sovereignty, O Bharata, belong to the Kshatriyas. All the wealth of the Earth is the Kshatriya's and not any one's else.

data.v: तदस्य स्याद्बलार्थं वा धनं यज्ञार्थमेव वा । अभोग्या ह्योषधीश्छित्त्वा भोग्या एव पचन्त्युत ॥
data.md: The Kshatriya should use that wealth for mairtaining his army and for the celebration of sacrifices. Tearing up useless creepers and plants, men burn them for cooking vegetables of food.

data.v: यो वै न देवान्न पितॄन्न मर्त्यान्हविषार्चति । आनन्तिकां तां धनितामाहुर्वेदविदो जनाः ॥
data.md: Men knowing duty have said that useless is his wealth who does not, with libations of clarificd butter, feed the gods, the Pitris, and men.

data.v: हरेत्तद्द्रविणं राजन्धार्मिकः पृथिवीपतिः । न हि तत्प्रीणयेल्लोकान्न कोशं तद्विधं नृपः ॥
data.md: O king, A virtuous ruler, should appropriate such riches. By that wealth, a large number of good people can be pleased. He should not, however, amass that wealth in his treasury.

data.v: असाधुभ्यो निरादाय साधुभ्यो यः प्रयच्छति । आत्मानं संक्रमं कृत्वा मन्ये धर्मविदेव सः ॥
data.md: He, who, himself being an instrument of acquisition, takes wealth from the wicked and gives it to the good, is said to be conversant with the virtue of adversity.

data.v: औद्भिज्जा जन्तवः केचिद्युक्तवाचो यथा तथा । अनिष्टतः संभवन्ति तथायज्ञः प्रतायते ॥
यथैव दंशमशकं यथा चाण्डपिपीलिकम् । सैव वृत्तिरयज्ञेषु तथा धर्मो विधीयते ॥
data.md: As flies, gnats, and ants are driven off from the bodies of kine and other domestic animals, so should all persons, who are averse to the celebration of sacrifices, should be similarly driven off from the kingdom. This is quite of a piece with morality.

data.v: यथा ह्यकस्माद्भवति भूमौ पांसुतृणोलपम् । तथैवेह भवेद्धर्मः सूक्ष्मः सूक्ष्मतरोऽपि च ॥
data.md: As being pounded between two stones, the dust becomes finer and finer, so questions of morality, the more they are discussed, becomes subtler and subtler.

data.v: अत्रैव चेदमव्यग्रः शृण्वाख्यानमनुत्तमम् । दीर्घसूत्रं समाश्रित्य कार्याकार्यविनिश्चये ॥
data.md: About it, listen attentively to the following excellent story of an idle person, who is expert to take decision in good or bed deeds.

data.v: नातिगाधे जलस्थाये सुहृदः शकुलास्त्रयः । प्रभूतमत्स्ये कौन्तेय बभूवुः सहचारिणः ॥
data.md: In shallow lake which abounded with fishes, there lived three Shakula fishes who were friends and constant companions.

data.v: अत्रैकः प्राप्तकालज्ञो दीर्घदर्शी तथापरः । दीर्घसूत्रश्च तत्रैकस्त्रयाणां जलचारिणाम् ॥
data.md: Of those three, one had much fore-thought always liked to provide for the future. Another had great presence of mind. The third was idle.

data.v: कदाचित्तज्जलस्थायं मत्स्यबन्धाः समन्ततः । निःस्रावयामासुरथो निम्नेषु विविधैर्मुखैः ॥
data.md: One day certain fishermen came to that lake and began to draw out its waters to a lower ground through various channels,

data.v: प्रक्षीयमाणं तं बुद्ध्वा जलस्थायं भयागमे । अब्रवीद्दीर्घदर्शी तु तावुभौ सुहृदौ तदा ॥
data.md: Seeing the water of the lake gradually decreasing, the fish that had much foresight, said to his two companions about the coming danger.

data.v: इयमापत्समुत्पन्ना सर्वेषां सलिलौकसाम् । शीघ्रमन्यत्र गच्छामः पन्था यावन्न दुष्यति ॥
data.md: A great danger is about to befall the aquatic animals living in this lake. Let us quickly go to some other place before our path becomes obstructed.

data.v: अनागतमनर्थं हि सुनयैर्यः प्रबाधते । न स संशयमाप्नोति रोचतां वां व्रजामहे ॥
data.md: He, who resists future evil by the help of good policy, never meets with serious danger. You follow my advice. Lest us all quit this place.

data.v: दीर्घसूत्रस्तु यस्तत्र सोऽब्रवीत्सम्यगुच्यते । न तु कार्या त्वरा यावदिति मे निश्चिता मतिः ॥
data.md: That one, amongst the three, who was idle then answered,-It is well said. There is, however, no necessity of such haste. This is my opinion.

data.v: अथ संप्रतिपत्तिज्ञः प्राब्रवीद्दीर्घदर्शिनम् । प्राप्ते काले न मे किंचिन्न्यायतः परिहास्यते ॥
data.md: Then the other fish, who had presence of mind, said to his idle companion,-When the time for anything comes, I take the necessary precautions.

data.v: एवमुक्तो निराक्रामद्दीर्घदर्शी महामतिः । जगाम स्रोतसैकेन गम्भीरसलिलाशयम् ॥
data.md: Hearing the replies of his two companions, the one, which had fore-thought and intelligence, immediately started by a current and reached another deep lake.

data.v: ततः प्रस्रुततोयं तं समीक्ष्य सलिलाशयम् । बबन्धुर्विविधैर्योगैर्मत्स्यान्मत्स्योपजीविनः ॥
data.md: Seeing that all the water had been drawn out, the fishermen shut in the fishes which remained by various means.

data.v: विलोड्यमाने तस्मिंस्तु स्रुततोये जलाशये । अगच्छद्ग्रहणं तत्र दीर्घसूत्रः सहापरैः ॥
data.md: Then they began to agitate the little remaining water, and as they began to catch the fish, the idle Shakula was caught with many others.

data.v: उद्दानं क्रियमाणं च मत्स्यानां वीक्ष्य रज्जुभिः । प्रविश्यान्तरमन्येषामग्रसत्प्रतिपत्तिमान् ॥
ग्रस्तमेव तदुद्दानं गृहीत्वास्त तथैव सः । सर्वानेव तु तांस्तत्र ते विदुर्ग्रथिता इति ॥
ततः प्रक्षाल्यमानेषु मत्स्येषु विमले जले । त्यक्त्वा रज्जुं विमुक्तोऽभूच्छीघ्रं संप्रतिपत्तिमान् ॥
data.md: They then removed them to a deep, water for washing them, Just then the Shakula known for presence of mind, left the string, and quickly escaped.

data.v: दीर्घसूत्रस्तु मन्दात्मा हीनबुद्धिरचेतनः । मरणं प्राप्तवान्मूढो यथैवोपहतेन्द्रियः ॥
data.md: That fish, however, who had been idle. foolish, and senseless and without intelligence, and, therefore, unable to escape, met with his death.

data.v: एवं प्राप्ततमं कालं यो मोहान्नावबुध्यते । स विनश्यति वै क्षिप्रं दीर्घसूत्रो यथा झषः ॥
data.md: Like the idle fish, who from want of intelligence could not forsee the danger, every one meets with destruction.

data.v: आदौ न कुरुते श्रेयः कुशलोऽस्मीति यः पुमान् । स संशयमवाप्नोति यथा संप्रतिपत्तिमान् ॥
data.md: Again, a man, who knowing himself as clever, does not seek his own good improper time, is visited by great dangers like the Shakula who had presence of mind.

data.v: अनागतविधानं तु यो नरः कुरुते क्षमम् । श्रेयः प्राप्नोति सोऽत्यर्थं दीर्घदर्शी यथा ह्यसौ ॥
कलाः काष्ठा मुहूर्ताश्च दिना नाड्यः क्षणा लवाः । पक्षा मासाश्च ऋतवस्तुल्याः संवत्सराणि च ॥
पृथिवी देश इत्युक्तः कालः स च न दृश्यते । अभिप्रेतार्थसिद्ध्यर्थं न्यायतो यच्च तत्तथा ॥
data.md: The divisions of the Earth are called place. Time is not seen. Regarding the success of any object or purpose, it is gained or not gained according to the manner in which the mind is engaged to think of it.

data.v: एतौ धर्मार्थशास्त्रेषु मोक्षशास्त्रेषु चर्षिभिः । प्रधानाविति निर्दिष्टौ कामेशाभिमतौ नृणाम् ॥
data.md: Therefore, the person of forethought and the person of presence of mind, have been described by the Rishis, to be the foremost of men in all works on virtue, profit and emancipation.

data.v: परीक्ष्यकारी युक्तस्तु सम्यक्समुपपादयेत् । देशकालावभिप्रेतौ ताभ्यां फलमवाप्नुयात् ॥
data.md: One, however, who does everything after reflection and scrutiny, one, who takes the advantage of proper means for the achievement of his objects, always succeeds in achieving much. Those, again, who work with proper attention to time and place, succeed in acquiring fruits better than the mere man of foresight and the man of presence of mind.'

data.v: सर्वत्र बुद्धिः कथिता श्रेष्ठा ते भरतर्षभ । अनागता तथोत्पन्ना दीर्घसूत्रा विनाशिनी ॥
data.md: Yudhishthira said You have, O foremost of Bharata's race, said that, that intelligence which provides for the future, as well as that which can meet present difficulties, is always superior, while idleness brings about destruction.

data.v: तदिच्छामि परां बुद्धिं श्रोतुं भरतसत्तम । यथा राजन्न मुह्येत शत्रुभिः परिवारितः ॥
धर्मार्थकुशल प्राज्ञ सर्वशास्त्रविशारद । पृच्छामि त्वा कुरुश्रेष्ठ तन्मे व्याख्यातुमर्हसि ॥
data.md: I wish, O grandfather, to hear of that superior intelligence by which king, conversant with the scriptures and well-versed in virtue and profit, may not be stupefied even when surrounded by many enemies. I ask you this, O Kuru chief! You should describe it to a me.

data.v: शत्रुभिर्बहुभिर्ग्रस्तो यथा वर्तेत पार्थिवः । एतदिच्छाम्यहं श्रोतुं सर्वमेव यथाविधि ॥
data.md: I wish to hear everything in connection with the duties of king when he is attacked by many foes, as has been laid down in the scriptures.

data.v: विषमस्थं हि राजानं शत्रवः परिपन्थिनः । बहवोऽप्येकमुद्धर्तुं यतन्ते पूर्वतापिताः ॥
data.md: When a king meets with distress, a large number of enemies, provoked by his past deeds, rise against him and try to defeat him.

data.v: सर्वतः प्रार्थ्यमानेन दुर्बलेन महाबलैः । एकेनैवासहायेन शक्यं स्थातुं कथं भवेत् ॥
data.md: How can king, weak and alone, hold his own, when attacked on all sides by many powerful kings joined in a body?

data.v: कथं मित्रमरिं चैव विन्देत भरतर्षभ । चेष्टितव्यं कथं चात्र शत्रोर्मित्रस्य चान्तरे ॥
data.md: How does a king at such times make friends and enemies? How should he, O foremost of Bharata's race, treat at such a time, both his friends and enemies?

data.v: प्रज्ञातलक्षणे राजन्नमित्रे मित्रतां गते । कथं नु पुरुषः कुर्यात्किं वा कृत्वा सुखी भवेत् ॥
data.md: When those, who are friends really become his enemies, what should the king then do if he is to secure happiness?

data.v: विग्रहं केन वा कुर्यात्संधिं वा केन योजयेत् । कथं वा शत्रुमध्यस्थो वर्तेताबलवानिति ॥
data.md: With whom should he make war and with whom should he make peace? Even if he be strong, how should he act by his foes?

data.v: एतद्वै सर्वकृत्यानां परं कृत्यं परंतप । नैतस्य कश्चिद्वक्तास्ति श्रोता चापि सुदुर्लभः ॥
data.md: O scorcher of foes, this I consider to be the most momentous of all questions regarding the satisfaction of royal duties. There are few men, who wish to listen to the answer of this question, and none answer it except Shantanu's truthful son Bhishma, who has ail his senses under control. O you, who are highly blessed, think on it and describe it to me. to

data.v: ऋते शांतनवाद्भीष्मात्सत्यसंधाज्जितेन्द्रियात् । तदन्विष्य महाबाहो सर्वमेतद्वदस्व मे ॥
त्वद्युक्तोऽयमनुप्रश्नो युधिष्ठिर गुणोदयः । शृणु मे पुत्र कार्त्स्न्येन गुह्यमापत्सु भारत ॥
data.md: 'O Yudhishthira, this question certainly becomes you. Its answer yields great happiness. Listen to me, O son, as I describe to you, O Bharata, all the duties which are not generaliy known, but which should be practised in times of distress.

data.v: अमित्रो मित्रतां याति मित्रं चापि प्रदुष्यति । सामर्थ्ययोगात्कार्याणां तद्गत्या हि सदा गतिः ॥
data.md: An enemy becomes a friend, and a friend also becomes an enemy. Through combination of circumstances, human actions become uncertain.

data.v: तस्माद्विश्वसितव्यं च विग्रहं च समाचरेत् । देशं कालं च विज्ञाय कार्याकार्यविनिश्चये ॥
data.md: Regarding what should be done and what should not, it is necessary that in view of the requirements of time and place, one should either trust one's enemies or make war.

data.md: Trying his very best, one should make friends with intelligent and wise men who desire his welfare. one should make peace with even his enemy, when, O Bharata his life cannot be saved by any other means.

data.md: That foolish wight, who never makes peace with enemies, cannot acquire any profit or any of those fruits for which others try.

data.md: He, again, who makes peace with enemies and falls out with even friends after carefully considering all circumstances, acquires great fruits.

data.md: Bhishma said There was a huge banian tree in the midst of a vast forest. Covered with many sorts of creepers, and various sorts of birds used to live on it.

data.md: A highly wise mouse, named Palita, lived at the foot of that tree, having made a hole there with a hundred outlets.

data.md: On the branches of the tree there lived happily a cat, by name Lomasha, daily devouring large number of birds.

data.v: तत्र चागत्य चण्डालो वैरन्त्यकृतकेतनः । अयोजयत्तमुन्माथं नित्यमस्तं गते रवौ ॥
data.md: Sometime after, a Chandala came to that forest and built a hut for himself. Every evening after sunset he spread his traps.

data.md: Spreading his nets made a leathern strings, he returned to his hut, and, passing the night happily in sleep, returned thert at the dawn of day.

data.v: तत्र स्म नित्यं बध्यन्ते नक्तं बहुविधा मृगाः । कदाचित्तत्र मार्जारस्त्वप्रमत्तोऽप्यबध्यत ॥
data.md: Various sorts of animals fell into his traps nightly. And it so took place that one day the cat in a moment of carelessness was caught in the trap.

data.md: O you of great wisdom, when his enemy the cat, who is always an enemy of the mice, was thus caught in the trap, the mouse Palita came out of his hole and began to move about fearlessly.

data.md: While confidently passing through the forest in search of food, the mouse after a little while saw the meat.

data.v: स तमुन्माथमारुह्य तदामिषमभक्षयत् । तस्योपरि सपत्नस्य बद्धस्य मनसा हसन् ॥
data.md: Getting upon the trap, the little animal began to eat the flesh. Laughing in his mind, he even got upon his enemy caught in the net.

data.md: Busy with eating the flesh, did not see his own danger, and as he suddenly cast his eyes, he saw there a dreadful enemy of his.

data.v: शरप्रसूनसंकाशं महीविवरशायिनम् । नकुलं हरिकं नाम चपलं ताम्रलोचनम् ॥
data.md: It was a restless mongoose of coppery eyes, of the name of Harita. Living in holes underneath, its body resembled the flower of a reed.

आपद्यस्यां सुकष्टायां मरणे समुपस्थिते । समन्ताद्भय उत्पन्ने कथं कार्यं हितैषिणा ॥
data.md: In such a great danger, when death itself is staring me in the face, when fear prevails on every side, how should one act who seeks his own well being?

data.v: स तथा सर्वतो रुद्धः सर्वत्र समदर्शनः । अभवद्भयसंतप्तश्चक्रे चेमां परां गतिम् ॥
data.md: Beset with danger, and seeing fear on all sides, the mouse, stricken with fear for his safety, made a high resolution.

data.md: Preventing numberless dangers by hundreds of means, one should always save his life. Danger, now, besets me on every side.

data.v: गतं हि सहसा भूमिं नकुलो मां समाप्नुयात् । उलूकश्चेह तिष्ठन्तं मार्जारः पाशसंक्षयात् ॥
data.md: If I were to descend from this trap on the ground, without sufficient precautions, the mongoose will surely catch and devour me. If I remain on this trap, the owl will surely catch me. If, again, the cat can free himself for the net, he, also, is certain to devour me.

data.v: न त्वेवास्मद्विधः प्राज्ञः संमोहं गन्तुमर्हति । करिष्ये जीविते यत्नं यावदुच्छ्वासनिग्रहम् ॥
data.md: It is not proper, therefore, that a person intelligent like myself should lose his wits. I shall, therefore, try me best to save my life, by having recourse to proper means and intelligence.

data.v: न हि बुद्ध्यान्विताः प्राज्ञा नीतिशास्त्रविशारदाः । संभ्रमन्त्यापदं प्राप्य महतोऽर्थानवाप्य च ॥
data.md: An intelligent and wise person and conversant with the science of policy never sinks, however great and terrible may be the danger which threatens him.

data.v: न त्वन्यामिह मार्जाराद्गतिं पश्यामि सांप्रतम् । विषमस्थो ह्ययं जन्तुः कृत्यं चास्य महन्मया ॥
data.md: At present, however, I do not see any other refuge than this cat. He is an enemy. But he is in difficulty. The service that I can do him is verygreat.

data.v: जीवितार्थी कथं त्वद्य प्रार्थितः शत्रुभिस्त्रिभिः । तस्मादिममहं शत्रुं मार्जारं संश्रयामि वै ॥
data.md: Three enemies are trying to devour me, and how should I now act for saving my life? I should now seek refuge with one of those enemies, viz., the cat.

data.v: क्षत्रविद्यां समाश्रित्य हितमस्योपधारये । येनेमं शत्रुसंघातं मतिपूर्वेण वञ्चये ॥
data.md: Following policy, let me advice the cat for his behoof, so that I may, with my intelligence, escape from all three.

data.v: अयमत्यन्तशत्रुर्मे वैषम्यं परमं गतः । मूढो ग्राहयितुं स्वार्थं संगत्या यदि शक्यते ॥
data.md: The cat is my great enemy, but the danger into which he has fallen is very great. Let me see if I can make this foolish creature understand his own interests. Having fallen into such difficulty he may make peace with me.

data.v: कदाचिद्व्यसनं प्राप्य संधिं कुर्यान्मया सह । बलिना संनिविष्टस्य शत्रोरपि परिग्रहः । कार्य इत्याहुराचार्या विषमे जीवितार्थिना ॥
data.md: A person, when attacked by a stronger one, should make peace with even an enemy. People conversant with policy say that such should be the conduct of one, who being beset with danger seeks to save his life.

data.v: श्रेयान्हि पण्डितः शत्रुर्न च मित्रमपण्डितम् । मम ह्यमित्रे मार्जारे जीवितं संप्रतिष्ठितम् ॥
data.md: It is better to have a learned person for an enemy than a fool for a friend. As for myself, my life now depends entirely on the hands of my enemy the cat.

data.v: हन्तैनं संप्रवक्ष्यामि हेतुमात्माभिरक्षणे । अपीदानीमयं शत्रुः संगत्या पण्डितो भवेत् ॥
data.md: I shall now speak to the cat about his own liberation. Perhaps, now it would not be wrong to consider the cat an intelligent and learned enemy. Thus did that mouse, surrounded by foes, think.

data.v: ततोऽर्थगतितत्त्वज्ञः संधिविग्रहकालवित् । सान्त्वपूर्वमिदं वाक्यं मार्जारं मूषकोऽब्रवीत् ॥
data.md: Having thought thus, the mouse, well-read in the science of Profit and well-acquainted with times when war should be declared and peace made, gently spoke to the cat, saying,

data.v: सौहृदेनाभिभाषे त्वा कच्चिन्मार्जार जीवसि । जीवितं हि तवेच्छामि श्रेयः साधारणं हि नौ ॥
data.md: I speak to you as a friend. O cat! Are you alive? I wish you to live! I seek the good of us both.

data.v: न ते सौम्य विषत्तव्यं जीविष्यसि यथा पुरा । अहं त्वामुद्धरिष्यामि प्राणाञ्जह्यां हि ते कृते ॥
data.md: O amiable one, you have no cause for fear. You will live in happiness! I shall save you, If, indeed, you do not kill me.

data.v: अस्ति कश्चिदुपायोऽत्र पुष्कलः प्रतिभाति माम् । येन शक्यस्त्वया मोक्षः प्राप्तुं श्रेयो यथा मया ॥
data.md: There is a very good means I see by which you may obtain escape and I may acquire great benefit.

data.v: मया ह्युपायो दृष्टोऽयं विचार्य मतिमात्मनः । आत्मार्थं च त्वदर्थं च श्रेयः साधारणं हि नौ ॥
data.md: By thinking I have found out this expedient for your sake and for my sake, for it will do us both good.

data.v: इदं हि नकुलोलूकं पापबुद्ध्यभितः स्थितम् । न धर्षयति मार्जार तेन मे स्वस्ति सांप्रतम् ॥
data.md: There are the mongoose and the owl, both waiting with evil desire. O cat, so long as they do not attack me, my life is safe.

data.v: कूजंश्चपलनेत्रोऽयं कौशिको मां निरीक्षते । नगशाखाग्रहस्तिष्ठंस्तस्याहं भृशमुद्विजे ॥
data.md: There that wretched owl with restless looks and dreadful cries is seeing me from the branch of that tree! I am stricken with great fear.

data.v: सतां साप्तपदं सख्यं सवासो मेऽसि पण्डितः । सांवास्यकं करिष्यामि नास्ति ते मृत्युतो भयम् ॥
data.md: Good men become friends by walking together only seven steps. Highly wise as you are, you are my friend. I shall treat you as a friend. You need have no fear now.

data.md: You have lived on this tree and I have lived at its foot. Both of us have lived here for many long years, All this is known to you.

data.v: यस्मिन्नाश्वसते कश्चिद्यश्च नाश्वसते क्वचित् । न तौ धीराः प्रशंसन्ति नित्यमुद्विग्नचेतसौ ॥
data.md: The wise never laud him whom nobody trusts, nor him who never trusts another. Both of them are unhappy.

data.v: तस्माद्विवर्धतां प्रीतिः सत्या संगतिरस्तु नौ । कालातीतमपार्थं हि न प्रशंसन्ति पण्डिताः ॥
data.md: Therefore, let our love for each other increase, and let us be united. The wise never speak highly of the attempt of doing an act when its opportunity is gone.

data.v: अर्थयुक्तिमिमां तावद्यथाभूतां निशामय । तव जीवितमिच्छामि त्वं ममेच्छसि जीवितम् ॥
data.md: Know this to be the proper time for such a compact between us. I wish that you should live, and you also wish that I should live.

data.md: Hearing these well-selected, reasonable and good words of the mouse, the mouse's enemy, endued with judgement and forethought, the cat said these words in reply.

data.md: Reflecting upon his own condition, the highly intelligent and eloquent cat praised the words of the speaker and honoured him by gentle words.

data.v: ततस्तीक्ष्णाग्रदशनो वैडूर्यमणिलोचनः । मूषकं मन्दमुद्वीक्ष्य मार्जारो लोमशोऽब्रवीत् ॥
data.md: Quietly looking at the mouse, the cat, called Lomasha, having sharp foreteeth and having eyes that resemble the stones called lapis lazuli answered as followsनन्दामि सौम्य भद्रं ते यो मां जीवितुमिच्छसि।

data.v: नन्दामि सौम्य भद्रं ते यो मां जीवन्तमिच्छसि । श्रेयश्च यदि जानीषे क्रियतां मा विचारय ॥
data.md: I am pleased with you, O amiable one! Blessed be you who wish me to live! Do that, without hesitation, which you think would do us good.

data.v: अहं हि दृढमापन्नस्त्वमापन्नतरो मया । द्वयोरापन्नयोः संधिः क्रियतां मा विचारय ॥
data.md: I am surely in great distress. You are, if possible, in greater distress still! Let there be an agreement made between us forthwith.

data.md: I will do that which is opportune and necessary for the success of our business, O powerful one! If you save me, your service will not go for nothing.

data.v: न्यस्तमानोऽस्मि भक्तोऽस्मि शिष्यस्त्वद्धितकृत्तथा । निदेशवशवर्ती च भवन्तं शरणं गतः ॥
data.md: I leave myself in your hands I am devoted to you. I shall attend and serve you like a disciple. I seek refuge with you and shall always obey you.

data.v: इत्येवमुक्तः पलितो मार्जारं वशमागतम् । वाक्यं हितमुवाचेदमभिनीतार्थमर्थवत् ॥
data.md: Thus accosted, the mouse Palita, speaking again to the cat, who was entirely under his control, said these highly significant and wise words-

data.v: उदारं यद्भवानाह नैतच्चित्रं भवद्विधे । विदितो यस्तु मार्गो मे हितार्थं शृणु तं मम ॥

data.md: I will crouch myself beneath your body. I am in great fear of the mongoose. Do you save me. Kill me not. I am capable to save you.

data.v: उलूकाच्चैव मां रक्ष क्षुद्रः प्रार्थयते हि माम् । अहं छेत्स्यामि ते पाशान्सखे सत्येन ते शपे ॥
तद्वचः संगतं श्रुत्वा लोमशो युक्तमर्थवत् । हर्षादुद्वीक्ष्य पलितं स्वागतेनाभ्यपूजयत् ॥
data.md: Hearing the words of the mouse at that proper time, knowing very useful Lomasha praised him looking with a smile.

data.v: स तं संपूज्य पलितं मार्जारः सौहृदे स्थितः । सुविचिन्त्याब्रवीद्धीरः प्रीतस्त्वरित एव हि ॥
data.md: Having praised Palita, the cat which was friendly disposed, thought for a moment, and gladly said without losing any time,-

data.v: क्षिप्रमागच्छ भद्रं ते त्वं मे प्राणसमः सखा । तव प्राज्ञ प्रसादाद्धि क्षिप्रं प्राप्स्यामि जीवितम् ॥
data.md: Come quickly to me. Blessed be you, who are, indeed, a friend dear to me as life.o you of great wisdom, through your grace I have almost regained my life.

data.v: यद्यदेवंगतेनाद्य शक्यं कर्तुं मया तव । तदाज्ञापय कर्ताहं संधिरेवास्तु नौ सखे ॥
data.md: Whatever I can do, tell me and I shall do it for your. Let there be peace between us, O friend.

data.v: अस्मात्ते संशयान्मुक्तः समित्रगणबान्धवः । सर्वकार्याणि कर्ताहं प्रियाणि च हितानि च ॥
data.md: Freed from this danger, I shall with all iny friends and relatives, do what is agreeable and good to you.

data.v: मुक्तश्च व्यसनादस्मात्सौम्याहमपि नाम ते । प्रीतिमुत्पादयेयं च प्रतिकर्तुं च शक्नुयाम् ॥
data.md: O amiable one, freed from this danger, I shall surely try to please you, and adore and honour you on every occasion in return for your good offices.

data.v: ग्राहयित्वा तु तं स्वार्थं मार्जारं मूषकस्तदा । प्रविवेश सुविस्रब्धः सम्यगर्थांश्चचार ह ॥
data.md: Bhishma said Having thus made the cat understand his own interests, the mouse truthfully crouched beneath his enemy's body.

data.v: एवमाश्वासितो विद्वान्मार्जारेण स मूषकः । मार्जारोरसि विस्रब्धः सुष्वाप पितृमातृवत् ॥
data.md: Learned, and thus assured by the cat, the mouse confidently laid himself thus under the breast of the cat as if it were the lap of his father or of his mother.

data.v: लीनं तु तस्य गात्रेषु मार्जारस्याथ मूषकम् । तौ दृष्ट्वा नकुलोलूकौ निराशौ जग्मतुर्गृहान् ॥
data.md: Seeing him thus enclosed within the body of the cat, the mongoose and the owl both gave up hopes of catching their prey.

data.v: लीनस्तु तस्य गात्रेषु पलितो देशकालवित् । चिच्छेद पाशान्नृपते कालाकाङ्क्षी शनैः शनैः ॥
data.md: Thereafter, the mouse Palita, who knew well the requirements of time and place, began, as he lay under the body of the cat, to cut the strings of the noose slowly, waiting for the proper time to finish his work.

data.v: अथ बन्धपरिक्लिष्टो मार्जारो वीक्ष्य मूषकम् । छिन्दन्तं वै तदा पाशानत्वरन्तं त्वरान्वितः ॥
data.md: Pained by the strings that fettered him, the cat became impatient upon seeing the mouse slowly cutting away the noose.

data.v: तमत्वरन्तं पलितं पाशानां छेदने तदा । संचोदयितुमारेभे मार्जारो मूषकं तदा ॥
data.md: Seeing the mouse so slow in the work, the cat wishing to hurry it on, said-How is it, O amiable one, that you do not proceed quickly with your work? Do you disregard me now, having accomplished your own work? O slayer of foes, cut off these strings quickly! The hunter will soon come hereइत्युक्तस्त्वरता तेन मतिमान् पलितोऽब्रवीत्।

data.v: किं सौम्य नाभित्वरसे किं कृतार्थोऽवमन्यसे । छिन्धि पाशानमित्रघ्न पुरा श्वपच एति सः ॥
data.md: Seeing the mouse so slow in the work, the cat wishing to hurry it on, said-How is it, O amiable one, that you do not proceed quickly with your work? Do you disregard me now, having accomplished your own work? O slayer of foes, cut off these strings quickly! The hunter will soon come hereइत्युक्तस्त्वरता तेन मतिमान् पलितोऽब्रवीत्।

data.v: इत्युक्तस्त्वरता तेन मतिमान्पलितोऽब्रवीत् । मार्जारमकृतप्रज्ञं वश्यमात्महितं वचः ॥
तूष्णीं भव न ते सौम्य त्वरा कार्या न संभ्रमः । वयमेवात्र कालज्ञा न कालः परिहास्यते ॥
data.md: Wait silently, O amiable one! Quickness is not necessary. Remove all your fears. We know the requirements of time. We are not wasting time.

data.v: अकाले कृत्यमारब्धं कर्तुं नार्थाय कल्पते । तदेव काल आरब्धं महतेऽर्थाय कल्पते ॥
data.md: When a work is begun at an improper time, it never becomes profitable when finished. That act, however, which is undertaken at the proper time, yields rich fruits.

data.v: अकालविप्रमुक्तान्मे त्वत्त एव भयं भवेत् । तस्मात्कालं प्रतीक्षस्व किमिति त्वरसे सखे ॥
data.md: If you are freed at an improper time, I shall have to fear you. Therefore, do you wait for the proper moment. Do not be impatient, О friend.

data.v: यावत्पश्यामि चण्डालमायान्तं शस्त्रपाणिनम् । ततश्छेत्स्यामि ते पाशं प्राप्ते साधारणे भये ॥
data.md: When I shall see the hunter come here armed with weapons, I shall cut the strings at that very moment of fear to both of us.

data.v: तस्मिन्काले प्रमुक्तस्त्वं तरुमेवाधिरोहसि । न हि ते जीवितादन्यत्किंचित्कृत्यं भविष्यति ॥
data.md: Freed then, you will get upon the tree and not think of anything else except the safety of your own life.

data.v: ततो भवत्यतिक्रान्ते त्रस्ते भीते च लोमश । अहं बिलं प्रवेक्ष्यामि भवाञ्शाखां गमिष्यति ॥
data.md: And when you, O Lomasha, will fly away in fear, I shall enter my hole and you will ascend the tree.

data.v: एवमुक्तस्तु मार्जारो मूषकेणात्मनो हितम् । वचनं वाक्यतत्त्वज्ञो जीवितार्थी महामतिः ॥
data.md: Thus addressed by the mouse with these beneficial words, the intelligent and eloquent cat, impatient of saving his life, addressed the mouse in the following words.

data.v: अथात्मकृत्यत्वरितः सम्यक्प्रश्रयमाचरन् । उवाच लोमशो वाक्यं मूषकं चिरकारिणम् ॥
data.md: Indeed, the cat, who had quickly and properly carried his own part of the agreement, addressing the mouse who was not quick enough in fulfilling his part, said,-

data.v: न ह्येवं मित्रकार्याणि प्रीत्या कुर्वन्ति साधवः । यथा त्वं मोक्षितः कृच्छ्रात्त्वरमाणेन वै मया ॥
data.md: I saved you from a great danger with considerable promptness. Alas, honest persons never thus do the business of their friends. Filled with joy while doing it, they do it otherwise.

data.v: तथैव त्वरमाणेन त्वया कार्यं हितं मम । यत्नं कुरु महाप्राज्ञ यथा स्वस्त्यावयोर्भवेत् ॥
data.md: You should do quickly what is for my wellbeing. O you of great wisdom, do you try a little so that good may be done to both of us.

data.v: अथ वा पूर्ववैरं त्वं स्मरन्कालं विकर्षसि । पश्य दुष्कृतकर्मत्वं व्यक्तमायुःक्षयो मम ॥
data.md: If, however, remembering our former hostility you are only allowing the time to slip away, know, O wicked creature, that the consequence of this your act will surely lessen your own life.

data.v: यच्च किंचिन्मयाज्ञानात्पुरस्ताद्विप्रियं कृतम् । न तन्मनसि कर्तव्यं क्षमये त्वां प्रसीद मे ॥
data.md: If I have ever, before this, unknowingly done you any wrong, you should not bear it in mind. I beg your pardon. Be pleased with me.

data.v: तमेवंवादिनं प्राज्ञः शास्त्रविद्बुद्धिसंमतः । उवाचेदं वचः श्रेष्ठं मार्जारं मूषकस्तदा ॥
data.md: After the cat had said these words, the intelligent and wise mouse, well-read in the

data.v: श्रुतं मे तव मार्जार स्वमर्थं परिगृह्णतः । ममापि त्वं विजानीहि स्वमर्थं परिगृह्णतः ॥
data.md: I have, O cat, heard what you have said to further your own object. Listen, however, to me as I tell you what is proper for my own objects.

data.v: यन्मित्रं भीतवत्साध्यं यन्मित्रं भयसंहितम् । सुरक्षितं ततः कार्यं पाणिः सर्पमुखादिव ॥
data.md: That friendship which is beset with fear and which cannot be maintained without fear, should be preserved with great caution like the hand (of the snake-charmer) from the snake's fangs!

data.v: कृत्वा बलवता संधिमात्मानं यो न रक्षति । अपथ्यमिव तद्भुक्तं तस्यानर्थाय कल्पते ॥
data.md: The person that does not protect himself after having made an agreement with a stronger individual, sees that is yields instead of good.

data.v: न कश्चित्कस्यचिन्मित्रं न कश्चित्कस्यचित्सुहृत् । अर्थैरर्था निबध्यन्ते गजैर्वनगजा इव ॥
data.md: Nobody is nobody's friend; nobody is nobody's enemy; persons becomes friends or enemies only from motives of interest.

data.v: न हि कश्चित्कृते कार्ये कर्तारं समवेक्षते । तस्मात्सर्वाणि कार्याणि सावशेषाणि कारयेत् ॥
data.md: Interest brings interest even as tame elephants catch wild elephants. Again, when a work is done, the doer is hardly thought of. Therefore, all works should be so done that something may remain undone.

data.v: तस्मिन्कालेऽपि च भवान्दिवाकीर्तिभयान्वितः । मम न ग्रहणे शक्तः पलायनपरायणः ॥
छिन्नं तु तन्तुबाहुल्यं तन्तुरेकोऽवशेषितः । छेत्स्याम्यहं तदप्याशु निर्वृतो भव लोमश ॥
data.md: When I shall liberate you, you will, from fear of the hunter, fly away for your life without ever thinking of catching me. See, all the strings of this net have been cut by me. Only one remains to be cut. I will cut that also soon. Be comforted, O Lomasha.

data.v: तयोः संवदतोरेवं तथैवापन्नयोर्द्वयोः । क्षयं जगाम सा रात्रिर्लोमशं चाविशद्भयम् ॥
data.md: While the mouse and the cat were thus conversing, both in serious danger, the night gradually passed away. A great fear, however, possessed the heart of the cat.

data.v: ततः प्रभातसमये विकृतः कृष्णपिङ्गलः । स्थूलस्फिग्विकचो रूक्षः श्वचक्रपरिवारितः ॥
शङ्कुकर्णो महावक्त्रः पलितो घोरदर्शनः । परिघो नाम चण्डालः शस्त्रपाणिरदृश्यत ॥
तं दृष्ट्वा यमदूताभं मार्जारस्त्रस्तचेतनः । उवाच पलितं भीतः किमिदानीं करिष्यसि ॥
data.md: Seeing that who resembled a messenger of Yama, the cat was stricken with fear. Filled with fear, he addressed Palita, saying,-What will you do now?

data.v: अथ चापि सुसंत्रस्तौ तं दृष्ट्वा घोरदर्शनम् । क्षणेन नकुलोलूकौ नैराश्यं जग्मतुस्तदा ॥
बलिनौ मतिमन्तौ च संघातं चाप्युपागतौ । अशक्यौ सुनयात्तस्मात्संप्रधर्षयितुं बलात् ॥
data.md: Both of them were endued with strength and intelligence. Clever in catching their prey, though near, the mongoose and the owl could not make the mouse and the cat break that agreement.

data.v: कार्यार्थं कृतसंधी तौ दृष्ट्वा मार्जारमूषकौ । उलूकनकुलौ तूर्णं जग्मतुः स्वं स्वमालयम् ॥
data.md: Indeed, seeing the cat and the mouse make that agreement for fulfilling their mutual object, the mongoose and the owl both left that spot and repaired to their respective quarters.

data.v: ततश्चिच्छेद तं तन्तुं मार्जारस्य स मूषकः । विप्रमुक्तोऽथ मार्जारस्तमेवाभ्यपतद्द्रुमम् ॥
स च तस्माद्भयान्मुक्तो मुक्तो घोरेण शत्रुणा । बिलं विवेश पलितः शाखां भेजे च लोमशः ॥
उन्माथमप्यथादाय चण्डालो वीक्ष्य सर्वशः । विहताशः क्षणेनाथ तस्माद्देशादपाक्रमत् । जगाम च स्वभवनं चण्डालो भरतर्षभ ॥
data.md: Seeing everything, the hunter took up his net. His hopes defeated, he also quickly left that place.

data.v: ततस्तस्माद्भयान्मुक्तो दुर्लभं प्राप्य जीवितम् । बिलस्थं पादपाग्रस्थः पलितं लोमशोऽब्रवीत् ॥
अकृत्वा संविदं कांचित्सहसाहमुपप्लुतः । कृतज्ञं कृतकल्याणं कच्चिन्मां नाभिशङ्कसे ॥
गत्वा च मम विश्वासं दत्त्वा च मम जीवितम् । मित्रोपभोगसमये किं त्वं नैवोपसर्पसि ॥
data.md: Having created confidence in me and having given me my life, why do you not come to me at a time when friends should enjoy the sweets of friendship?

data.v: कृत्वा हि पूर्वं मित्राणि यः पश्चान्नानुतिष्ठति । न स मित्राणि लभते कृच्छ्रास्वापत्सु दुर्मतिः ॥
data.md: Having made friends, he who forgets them afterwards, is a wicked person and never gets friends at times of danger and necessity.

data.v: तत्कृतोऽहं त्वया मित्रं सामर्थ्यादात्मनः सखे । स मां मित्रत्वमापन्नमुपभोक्तुं त्वमर्हसि ॥
data.md: I have been, O friend, respected and served by you to the best of your power. You should now enjoy the company of my poor self who has become your friend.

data.v: यानि मे सन्ति मित्राणि ये च मे सन्ति बान्धवाः । सर्वे त्वां पूजयिष्यन्ति शिष्या गुरुमिव प्रियम् ॥
data.md: Like disciples adoring their preceptor, all the friends I have, all my relatives and kinsmen, will respect and adore you.

data.v: अहं च पूजयिष्ये त्वां समित्रगणबान्धवम् । जीवितस्य प्रदातारं कृतज्ञः को न पूजयेत् ॥
data.md: I myself too shall adore you with all your friends and kinsmen. What grateful person is there who will not adore the giver of his life.

data.v: ईश्वरो मे भवानस्तु शरीरस्य गृहस्य च । अर्थानां चैव सर्वेषामनुशास्ता च मे भव ॥
data.md: Be you the master of both my body and home! Be you the disposer of all my wealth and properties.

data.v: अमात्यो मे भव प्राज्ञ पितेव हि प्रशाधि माम् । न तेऽस्ति भयमस्मत्तो जीवितेनात्मनः शपे ॥
data.md: Be you my respected adviser and do you govern me like a father! I swear by my life that you need not fear us.

data.v: बुद्ध्या त्वमुशनाः साक्षाद्बले त्वधिकृता वयम् । त्वन्मन्त्रबलयुक्तो हि विन्देत जयमेव ह ॥
data.md: In intelligence you are like Ushanas himself. By the power of your understanding you have conquered us. Clever in policy, you have given us our life.

data.v: एवमुक्तः परं सान्त्वं मार्जारेण स मूषकः । उवाच परमार्थज्ञः श्लक्ष्णमात्महितं वचः ॥
data.md: Accosted thus with sweet words by the cat, the mouse, who knew all which produces the highest good, replied in these sweet words that were beneficial to himself.

data.v: यद्भवानाह तत्सर्वं मया ते लोमश श्रुतम् । ममापि तावद्ब्रुवतः शृणु यत्प्रतिभाति माम् ॥
data.md: I have heard, O Lomasha, all that you have, said. Listen now as I say what I think.

data.v: वेदितव्यानि मित्राणि बोद्धव्याश्चापि शत्रवः । एतत्सुसूक्ष्मं लोकेऽस्मिन्दृश्यते प्राज्ञसंमतम् ॥
data.md: Friends should be well tried. Enemies also should be well studied. In this world, a task like this is considered by even the learned as a difficult one requiring sharp intelligence.

data.v: शत्रुरूपाश्च सुहृदो मित्ररूपाश्च शत्रवः । सान्त्वितास्ते न बुध्यन्ते रागलोभवशं गताः ॥
data.md: Friends appear like enemies, and enemies appear like friends. When agreements of friendship are made, it is difficult for the parties to know whether they are really actuated by lust and anger.

data.v: नास्ति जात्या रिपुर्नाम मित्रं नाम न विद्यते । सामर्थ्ययोगाज्जायन्ते मित्राणि रिपवस्तथा ॥
data.md: There is no such thing as a friend. It is circumstances which make friends and enemies.

data.v: यो यस्मिञ्जीवति स्वार्थं पश्येत्तावत्स जीवति । स तस्य तावन्मित्रं स्याद्यावन्न स्याद्विपर्ययः ॥

data.md: There is no condition that passes for ever by the name either of friendship or enemies. Both friends and enemies arise from considerations of interest and gain.

data.v: मित्रं च शत्रुतामेति कस्मिंश्चित्कालपर्यये । शत्रुश्च मित्रतामेति स्वार्थो हि बलवत्तरः ॥
data.md: Friendship becomes enmity in the course of time. An enemy also becomes a friend. Selfinterest is very powerful.

data.v: यो विश्वसति मित्रेषु न चाश्वसति शत्रुषु । अर्थयुक्तिमविज्ञाय चलितं तस्य जीवितम् ॥
data.md: He, who blindly places confidence in friends and always treats enemies mistrustfully without paying any heed to considerations of policy, finds his life unsafe. He, who, neglecting all considerations of policy, seeks either friends or foes, is regarded as a person whose understanding has been unhinged.

data.v: अर्थयुक्तिमविज्ञाय यः शुभे कुरुते मतिम् । मित्रे वा यदि वा शत्रौ तस्यापि चलिता मतिः ॥

data.md: One should not trust a person undeserving of truth, nor should one trust too much a person worthy of trust. The anger from blind confidence is such that it cuts the very roots.

data.md: The father, the mother, the son, the maternal uncle, the sister's son, and other relatives and kinsmen, are all moved by interest and profit.

data.md: Father and mother may be seen to discard the dear son if he is addicted to irregular practices. People take care of their own selves. See the efficacy of self-interest.

data.md: O highly wise one, his escape is very difficult, who, immediately after he is freed from danger, seeks the means of his enemy's happiness.

data.md: You have come down from the top of the tree to this very spot. You could not, from foolishness know that a net had been spread here.

data.v: आत्मनश्चपलो नास्ति कुतोऽन्येषां भविष्यति । तस्मात्सर्वाणि कार्याणि चपलो हन्त्यसंशयम् ॥
data.md: A person, who has no sense, cannot protect his own self. How can be protect others? Such a person, forsooth, ruins all his acts.

data.v: ब्रवीति मधुरं कंचित्प्रियो मे ह भवानिति । तन्मिथ्याकरणं सर्वं विस्तरेणापि मे शृणु ॥
data.md: You speak sweetly that I am very dear to you. Hear me, however, O friends, the reasons which I have on my side.

data.v: कारणात्प्रियतामेति द्वेष्यो भवति कारणात् । अर्थार्थी जीवलोकोऽयं न कश्चित्कस्यचित्प्रियः ॥
data.md: One becomes dear from a sufficient cause. One becomes an enemy from sufficient cause. The entire world of creatures is actuated by the desire of gain. One never becomes dear to another without cause.

data.md: The friendship between two uterine brothers, the love between husband and wife, rests upon interest. I do not know any kind of love amongst persons that does not depend upon some motive of self-interest. It is sometimes seen that uterine brothers or husband and wife having quarrelled are united again from a natural affection. But such a thing is not to be seen in persons who are not connected with one another.

data.v: प्रियो भवति दानेन प्रियवादेन चापरः । मन्त्रहोमजपैरन्यः कार्यार्थं प्रीयते जनः ॥
data.md: One becomes dear for his liberality. Another becomes dear for his sweet words. A third becomes so for his religious acts. Generally, a person becomes dear for the purpose he serves.

data.v: किं नु तत्कारणं मन्ये येनाहं भवतः प्रियः । अन्यत्राभ्यवहारार्थात्तत्रापि च बुधा वयम् ॥
data.md: What is that reason, I ask, for which I have become so dear to you, besides your desire for eating me up? You should know that I am not forgetful of this.

data.v: कालो हेतुं विकुरुते स्वार्थस्तमनुवर्तते । स्वार्थं प्राज्ञोऽभिजानाति प्राज्ञं लोकोऽनुवर्तते ॥
data.md: Time spoils reasons. You seek your own interests. Otherwise men, again, understand their own interests. The world is guided by the example of the wise. You should not thus speak to a person who is learned and capable of understanding his own interests.

data.v: न त्वीदृशं त्वया वाच्यं विदुषि स्वार्थपण्डिते । अकालेऽविषमस्थस्य स्वार्थहेतुरयं तव ॥
