data.v: अनिष्टानां सहस्राणि तथेष्टानां शतानि च । उत्सृज्येह प्रयाता वै बान्धवा भृशदुःखिताः ॥
data.md: Leaving here thousands of both friends and enemies, kinsmen stricken with grief go back to their homes.

data.v: त्यज्यतामेष निस्तेजाः शून्यः काष्ठत्वमागतः । अन्यदेहविषक्तो हि शावं काष्ठमुपासते ॥
data.md: Leave off this dead body which has no longer any animal heat in it and which is as stiff as a piece of wood. Why then do you not go away, leaving the body of this child which is like a piece of wood and whose life had entered a new body?

data.v: भ्रान्तजीवस्य वै बाष्पं कस्माद्धित्वा न गच्छथ । निरर्थको ह्ययं स्नेहो निरर्थश्च परिग्रहः ॥
न चक्षुर्भ्यां न कर्णाभ्यां संशृणोति समीक्षते । तस्मादेनं समुत्सृज्य स्वगृहान्गच्छताशु वै ॥
मोक्षधर्माश्रितैर्वाक्यैर्हेतुमद्भिरनिष्ठुरैः । मयोक्ता गच्छत क्षिप्रं स्वं स्वमेव निवेशनम् ॥
data.md: Leaving him here go away forthwith. Thus addressed by me in words which are seemingly cruel but which in reality are reasonable and are directly connected with the great religion of emancipation, return he to your respective homes.

data.v: प्रज्ञाविज्ञानयुक्तेन बुद्धिसंज्ञाप्रदायिना । वचनं श्राविता रूक्षं मानुषाः संनिवर्तत ॥
data.md: Addressed thus by the vulture gifted with wisdom and knowledge and capable of giving intelligence and awakening the understanding, those men were about to go away from the crematorium. Grief becomes two-fold two-fold on seeing its object and on remembering the acts of that object (in life).

data.v: इमं कनकवर्णाभं भूषणैः समलंकृतम् । गृध्रवाक्यात्कथं पुत्रं त्यजध्वं पितृपिण्डदम् ॥
data.md: Why, indeed, do you leave, at the vulture's suggestion, this child bearing golden hue, adorned with ornaments, and capable of giving the obsequial cake to his departed manes?

data.v: न स्नेहस्य विरोधोऽस्ति विलापरुदितस्य वै । मृतस्यास्य परित्यागात्तापो वै भविता ध्रुवम् ॥
data.md: If you abandon him, your love will not terminate, nor these piteous cries. On the other hand, your grief will multiply itself.

data.v: श्रूयते शम्बुके शूद्रे हते ब्राह्मणदारकः । जीवितो धर्ममासाद्य रामात्सत्यपराक्रमात् ॥
data.md: We have heard that a Shudra named Shambuka having been killed and virtue having been upheld by the powerful Rama, a (dead, Brahmana child was restored to life.

data.v: तथा श्वेतस्य राजर्षेर्बालो दिष्टान्तमागतः । श्वोऽभूते धर्मनित्येन मृतः संजीवितः पुनः ॥
data.md: Likewise the son of the royal sage Shveta had died (prematurely). But the virtuous monarch succeeded in reviving his dead child.

data.v: तथा कश्चिद्भवेत्सिद्धो मुनिर्वा देवतापि वा । कृपणानामनुक्रोशं कुर्याद्वो रुदतामिह ॥
data.md: Similarly, in your case also, some sage or god may be willing to grant your desire and show mercy to you that are crying piteously.

data.v: इत्युक्ताः संन्यवर्तन्त शोकार्ताः पुत्रवत्सलाः । अङ्के शिरः समाधाय रुरुदुर्बहुविस्तरम् ॥
data.md: Thus accosted by the jackai, the men, stricken with grief and full of affection for the child, returned, and placing the child's head on their laps one after another, began the bewail piteously. Hearing their cries, the vulture, coming there, once more spoke to them as follows.

data.v: अश्रुपातपरिक्लिन्नः पाणिस्पर्शनपीडितः । धर्मराजप्रयोगाच्च दीर्घां निद्रां प्रवेशितः ॥
data.md: The Vulture said Why are you bathing this child with your tears? Why are you pressing him with your palms in this way? At the behest of the grim king of justice the child has been sent to that sleep which will never be broken.

data.v: तपसापि हि संयुक्तो न काले नोपहन्यते । सर्वस्नेहावसानं तदिदं तत्प्रेतपत्तनम् ॥
data.md: Those who have acquired the merit of penances, those who are gifted with wealth, those who are endued with great intelligence, in fact, all yield to death. This is the place intended for the dead.

data.v: बालवृद्धसहस्राणि सदा संत्यज्य बान्धवाः । दिनानि चैव रात्रीश्च दुःखं तिष्ठन्ति भूतले ॥
data.md: It is always seen that casting off thousands of kinsmen, young and old kinsmen pass their nights and days in grief, rolling on the naked earth.

data.v: अलं निर्बन्धमागम्य शोकस्य परिवारणम् । अप्रत्ययं कुतो ह्यस्य पुनरद्येह जीवितम् ॥
data.md: Stop this ardour in putting on the trappings of woe. It is impossible that this child would be restored to life again.

data.v: नैष जम्बुकवाक्येन पुनः प्राप्स्यति जीवितम् । मृतस्योत्सृष्टदेहस्य पुनर्देहो न विद्यते ॥
न वै मूर्तिप्रदानेन न जम्बुकशतैरपि । शक्यो जीवयितुं ह्येष बालो वर्षशतैरपि ॥
data.md: By sacrificing their own lives, hundreds of jackals will not be able to revive this child in hundreds of years.

data.v: अपि रुद्रः कुमारो वा ब्रह्मा वा विष्णुरेव वा । वरमस्मै प्रयच्छेयुस्ततो जीवेदयं शिशुः ॥
data.md: If, however, Rudra, Kumara, Brahma, or Vishnu, grant him a boon, then only may this child be restored to life.

data.v: न च बाष्पविमोक्षेण न चाश्वासकृतेन वै । न दीर्घरुदितेनेह पुनर्जीवो भविष्यति ॥
data.md: Neither the shedding of tears, nor the heaving of long sighs, nor profuse lamentations, will restore this one to life.

data.v: अहं च क्रोष्टुकश्चैव यूयं चैवास्य बान्धवाः । धर्माधर्मौ गृहीत्वेह सर्वे वर्तामहेऽध्वनि ॥
अप्रियं परुषं चापि परद्रोहं परस्त्रियम् । अधर्ममनृतं चैव दूरात्प्राज्ञो निवर्तयेत् ॥
सत्यं धर्मं शुभं न्याय्यं प्राणिनां महतीं दयाम् । अजिह्मत्वमशाठ्यं च यत्नतः परिमार्गत ॥
मातरं पितरं चैव बान्धवान्सुहृदस्तथा । जीवतो ये न पश्यन्ति तेषां धर्मविपर्ययः ॥
यो न पश्यति चक्षुर्भ्यां नेङ्गते च कथंचन । तस्य निष्ठावसानान्ते रुदन्तः किं करिष्यथ ॥
data.md: What will you profit by crying, for him after death, who does not see with his eyes and stir in the least.

data.v: इत्युक्तास्तं सुतं त्यक्त्वा भूमौ शोकपरिप्लुताः । दह्यमानाः सुतस्नेहात्प्रययुर्बान्धवा गृहान् ॥
data.md: Thus addressed, the men, laden with sorrow and burning with grief on account of their love for the child, departed for their homes, leaving the body.

data.v: दारुणो मर्त्यलोकोऽयं सर्वप्राणिविनाशनः । इष्टबन्धुवियोगश्च तथैवाल्पं च जीवितम् ॥
data.md: The jackal said Alas, dreadful is this world of mortals! Here no creature can escape. Every creature's life is short. Beloved friends are always going.

data.v: बह्वलीकमसत्यं च प्रतिवादाप्रियंवदम् । इमं प्रेक्ष्य पुनर्भावं दुःखशोकाभिवर्धनम् ॥
data.md: It is full of vanities and falsehoods, accusations and evil reports! Witnessing again this incident which increases pain and grief, I do not for a moment like this world of men.

data.v: न मे मानुषलोकोऽयं मुहूर्तमपि रोचते । अहो धिग्गृध्रवाक्येन संनिवर्तथ मानुषाः ॥
प्रदीप्ताः पुत्रशोकेन यथैवाबुद्धयस्तथा । कथं गच्छथ सस्नेहाः सुतस्नेहं विसृज्य च । श्रुत्वा गृध्रस्य वचनं पापस्येहाकृतात्मनः ॥
data.md: Alas, shame on you, you men, who thus return like foolish persons, on hearing the vulture's words, though you are burning with grief on account of the death of this child. You cruel men, how can you go away, renouncing parental affection upon hearing the words of a sinful vulture of impure soul.

data.v: सुखस्यानन्तरं दुःखं दुःखस्यानन्तरं सुखम् । सुखदुःखान्विते लोके नेहास्त्येकमनन्तकम् ॥
इमं क्षितितले न्यस्य बालं रूपसमन्वितम् । कुलशोकाकरं मूढाः पुत्रं त्यक्त्वा क्व यास्यथ ॥
रूपयौवनसंपन्नं द्योतमानमिव श्रिया । जीवन्तमेनं पश्यामि मनसा नात्र संशयः ॥
विनाशश्चाप्यनर्होऽस्य सुखं प्राप्स्यथ मानुषाः । पुत्रशोकाग्निदग्धानां मृतमप्यद्य वः क्षमम् ॥
data.md: It is not proper that he should die. It seems that you are sure to gain happiness. You who are stricken with grief for the death of this child will, forsooth, have good luck to-day.

data.v: दुःखसंभावनां कृत्वा धारयित्वा स्वयं सुखम् । त्यक्त्वा गमिष्यथ क्वाद्य समुत्सृज्याल्पबुद्धिवत् ॥
data.md: Anticipating inconvenience and pain and seeking your own comfort, where will you, like persons of little intelligence, go, leaving this darling.

data.v: तथा धर्मविरोधेन प्रियमिथ्याभिध्यायिना । श्मशानवासिना नित्यं रात्रिं मृगयता तदा ॥
ततो मध्यस्थतां नीता वचनैरमृतोपमैः । जम्बुकेन स्वकार्यार्थं बान्धवास्तस्य धिष्ठिताः ॥
data.md: Bhishma said Thus, O king, the kinsmen of the dead child, unable to settle what they should do, were, for fulfilling his own purpose, induced by that sinful jackal who uttered sweet falsehoods-that dweller of the crematorium who went there every night in search of food.

data.v: अयं प्रेतसमाकीर्णो यक्षराक्षससेवितः । दारुणः काननोद्देशः कौशिकैरभिनादितः ॥
data.md: Dreadful is that spot, this wilderness, which resounds with the screams of owls and is filled with spirits and Yakshas and Rakshasas.

data.v: भीमः सुघोरश्च तथा नीलमेघसमप्रभः । अस्मिञ्शवं परित्यज्य प्रेतकार्याण्युपासत ॥
data.md: It appears dreadful like a mass of blue clouds. Casting off the body, perform the funeral rites.

data.v: भानुर्यावन्न यात्यस्तं यावच्च विमला दिशः । तावदेनं परित्यज्य प्रेतकार्याण्युपासत ॥
data.md: Throwing away the body, perform those rites before the sun sets and before the points of compass are covered with darkness.

data.v: नदन्ति परुषं श्येनाः शिवाः क्रोशन्ति दारुणाः । मृगेन्द्राः प्रतिनन्दन्ति रविरस्तं च गच्छति ॥
data.md: The hawks are uttering hideous cries. Jackals are howling hideously. Lions are roaring. The sun is setting.

data.v: चिताधूमेन नीलेन संरज्यन्ते च पादपाः । श्मशाने च निराहाराः प्रतिनन्दन्ति देहिनः ॥
data.md: The trees on the crematorium are appearing dark for the blue smoke of the funeral pyres. Stricken with hunger the carnivorous animals are yelling in rage.

data.v: सर्वे विक्रान्तवीर्याश्च अस्मिन्देशे सुदारुणाः । युष्मान्प्रधर्षयिष्यन्ति विकृता मांसभोजनाः ॥
data.md: All those creatures of dreadful forms which live in this fearful place, all those grim-visaged animals that haunt this desert, will soon attack you.

data.v: दूराच्चायं वनोद्देशो भयमत्र भविष्यति । त्यज्यतां काष्ठभूतोऽयं मृष्यतां जाम्बुकं वचः ॥
data.md: This forest is certainly dreadful. Danger will beset you. The child is like a dry wood. Indeed, if you listen to these false and useless words of the jackal against your own good sense, all of your will surely meet with death.

data.v: यदि जम्बुकवाक्यानि निष्फलान्यनृतानि च । श्रोष्यथ भ्रष्टविज्ञानास्ततः सर्वे विनङ्क्ष्यथ ॥
data.md: This forest is certainly dreadful. Danger will beset you. The child is like a dry wood. Indeed, if you listen to these false and useless words of the jackal against your own good sense, all of your will surely meet with death.

data.v: स्थीयतां नेह भेतव्यं यावत्तपति भास्करः । तावदस्मिन्सुतस्नेहादनिर्वेदेन वर्तत ॥
data.md: Remain where you are. There is no fear even in this desert as long as the sun shines. Do you remain herc hopefully, moved by parental affection till the sun sets.

data.v: स्वैरं रुदत विस्रब्धाः स्वैरं स्नेहेन पश्यत । स्थीयतां यावदादित्यः किं वः क्रव्यादभाषितैः ॥
यदि गृध्रस्य वाक्यानि तीव्राणि रभसानि च । गृह्णीत मोहितात्मानः सुतो वो न भविष्यति ॥
data.md: If, being stupefied, you follow the cruel and harsh words of the vulture, then your child will never regain life.

data.v: गृध्रोऽनस्तमिते त्वाह गतेऽस्तमिति जम्बुकः । मृतस्य तं परिजनमूचतुस्तौ क्षुधान्वितौ ॥
data.md: Bhishma said The vulture then said to those men, that the sun had set. The jackal said that it was not so. Both the vulture and the jackal fell hungry and thus addressed thc kinsmen of the dead child.

data.v: स्वकार्यदक्षिणौ राजन्गृध्रो जम्बुक एव च । क्षुत्पिपासापरिश्रान्तौ शास्त्रमालम्ब्य जल्पतः ॥
data.md: Both of them were deterinined upon accomplishing their respective purposes. Exhausted with hunger and thirst, they thus quarrelled, taking advantage of the scriptures.

data.v: तयोर्विज्ञानविदुषोर्द्वयोर्जम्बुकपत्रिणोः । वाक्यैरमृतकल्पैर्हि प्रातिष्ठन्त व्रजन्ति च ॥
data.md: Moved by these words, sweet as ambrosia, of those two creatures, viz., the bird and the beast, both of whom had wisdom and knowledge, the kinsmen at one time desired to go away and at another to remain there.

data.v: शोकदैन्यसमाविष्टा रुदन्तस्तस्थिरे तदा । स्वकार्यकुशलाभ्यां ते संभ्राम्यन्ते ह नैपुणात् ॥
data.md: At last, actuated by sorrow and depression, they waited there, bewailing piteously. They did not know that the beast and the bird, very clever in achieving their ends, had only stupefied them (by their words).

data.v: तथा तयोर्विवदतोर्विज्ञानविदुषोर्द्वयोः । बान्धवानां स्थितानां च उपातिष्ठत शंकरः ॥
data.md: While both the bird and the beast were thus disputing and while the kinsmen of the dead child sat listening to them, the great god Shankara, urged by his divine consort (Uma), arrived there with eyes bathed in tears of mercy.

data.v: ततस्तानाह मनुजान्वरदोऽस्मीति शूलभृत् । ते प्रत्यूचुरिदं वाक्यं दुःखिताः प्रणताः स्थिताः ॥
एकपुत्रविहीनानां सर्वेषां जीवितार्थिनाम् । पुत्रस्य नो जीवदानाज्जीवितं दातुमर्हसि ॥
एवमुक्तः स भगवान्वारिपूर्णेन पाणिना । जीवं तस्मै कुमाराय प्रादाद्वर्षशताय वै ॥
data.md: Thus begged, the illustrious god, taking up some water in his hands, granted to that dead child life extending for a hundred years.

data.v: तथा गोमायुगृध्राभ्यामददत्क्षुद्विनाशनम् । वरं पिनाकी भगवान्सर्वभूतहिते रतः ॥
data.md: Ever engaged in the behoof of all creatures, the illustrious holder of Pinaka granted a boon to both the jackal and the vulture for which their hunger was appeased.

data.v: ततः प्रणम्य तं देवं श्रेयोहर्षसमन्विताः । कृतकृत्याः सुखं हृष्टाः प्रातिष्ठन्त तदा विभो ॥
अनिर्वेदेन दीर्घेण निश्चयेन ध्रुवेण च । देवदेवप्रसादाच्च क्षिप्रं फलमवाप्यते ॥
पश्य देवस्य संयोगं बान्धवानां च निश्चयम् । कृपणानां हि रुदतां कृतमश्रुप्रमार्जनम् ॥
data.md: Mark the combination of circumstances and the determination of those kinsmen. While crying with heavy hearts, their tears were wiped and dried up.

data.v: पश्य चाल्पेन कालेन निश्चयान्वेषणेन च । प्रसादं शंकरात्प्राप्य दुःखिताः सुखमाप्नुवन् ॥
data.md: See, how within only a short time, through their firmness of resolution, they gained the grace of Shankara, and their sorrows removed, they were made happy.

data.v: ते विस्मिताः प्रहृष्टाश्च पुत्रसंजीवनात्पुनः । बभूवुर्भरतश्रेष्ठ प्रसादाच्छंकरस्य वै ॥
data.md: Indeed, through Shankara's favour, O chief of the Bharatas, those sorrowing kinsmen were filled with wonder and joy at the restoration of their child to life.

data.v: ततस्ते त्वरिता राजञ्श्रुत्वा शोकमघोद्भवम् । विविशुः पुत्रमादाय नगरं हृष्टमानसाः । एषा बुद्धिः समस्तानां चातुर्वर्ण्ये निदर्शिता ॥
data.md: Then, O king, shaking off that grief caused by their child, those Brahmanas, filled with joy, quickly returned to their town; taking the restored child with them. Such a conduct has been laid down for all the four castes.

data.v: धर्मार्थमोक्षसंयुक्तमितिहासमिमं शुभम् । श्रुत्वा मनुष्यः सततमिह प्रेत्य च मोदते ॥
data.md: By frequently listening to this auspicious story fraught with virtue, profit, and emancipation, a man acquires happiness both in this world and the next.'

data.v: अत्राप्युदाहरन्तीममितिहासं पुरातनम् । संवादं भरतश्रेष्ठ शल्मलेः पवनस्य च ॥
data.md: Regarding it is cited the old story of the conversation between Vishvamitra and the Chandala in a village of Chandalas.

data.v: हिमवन्तं समासाद्य महानासीद्वनस्पतिः । वर्षपूगाभिसंवृद्धः शाखास्कन्धपलाशवान् ॥
data.md: There was a huge (Shalmali) tree on one of the peaks of Himavat. Having grown for many hundred years, he had spread out his branches wide around. His trunk also was huge and his twigs and leaves were numberless.

data.v: तत्र स्म मत्ता मातङ्गा धर्मार्ताः श्रमकर्शिताः । विश्रमन्ति महाबाहो तथान्या मृगजातयः ॥
data.md: Under his shade elephants, exhausted and covered with temporal juice and sweat, used to rest, and as also many other animals.

data.v: नल्वमात्रपरीणाहो घनच्छायो वनस्पतिः । शुकशारिकसंघुष्टः फलवान्पुष्पवानपि ॥
data.md: The circumference of his trunk was four hundred cubits, and the shade of his branches and leaves was dense. Laden with flowers and fruits, it was the abode of numberless parrots male and female.

data.v: सार्थिका वणिजश्चापि तापसाश्च वनौकसः । वसन्ति वासान्मार्गस्थाः सुरम्ये तरुसत्तमे ॥
data.md: While travelling, caravans of merchants and traders, and ascetics living in the forest, used to rest under the shade of that charming king of the forest.

data.v: तस्या ता विपुलाः शाखा दृष्ट्वा स्कन्धांश्च सर्वतः । अभिगम्याब्रवीदेनं नारदो भरतर्षभ ॥
data.md: One day, O foremost of Bharata's race, seeing the wide-extending and numberless branches of that tree and the circumference of his trunk, the sage Narada, approached and addressed him, saying,-O, you are delightful! O, you are charming! O foremost of trees, O Shalmali, I am always pleased to see you.

data.v: अहो नु रमणीयस्त्वमहो चासि मनोरमः । प्रीयामहे त्वया नित्यं तरुप्रवर शल्मले ॥
data.md: One day, O foremost of Bharata's race, seeing the wide-extending and numberless branches of that tree and the circumference of his trunk, the sage Narada, approached and addressed him, saying,-O, you are delightful! O, you are charming! O foremost of trees, O Shalmali, I am always pleased to see you.

data.v: सदैव शकुनास्तात मृगाश्चाधस्तथा गजाः । वसन्ति तव संहृष्टा मनोहरतरास्तथा ॥
data.md: O charming tree, beautiful birds of various kinds, and elephants and other animals gladly live on your branches and under their shade.

data.v: तव शाखा महाशाख स्कन्धं च विपुलं तथा । न वै प्रभग्नान्पश्यामि मारुतेन कथंचन ॥
data.md: Your branches, O wide-branched king of the forest, are lofty and majestic as huge is your trunk! I never see any of them broken by the god of wind.

data.v: किं नु ते मारुतस्तात प्रीतिमानथ वा सुहृत् । त्वां रक्षति सदा येन वनेऽस्मिन्पवनो ध्रुवम् ॥
data.md: Is it, O child, because that Wind-god is pleased with you and is your friend so that he protects you always in these woods?

data.v: विवान्हि पवनः स्थानाद्वृक्षानुच्चावचानपि । पर्वतानां च शिखराण्याचालयति वेगवान् ॥
data.md: The illustrious Pavana of great speed and force unfixes the tallest and strongest trees, and even mountain summits.

data.v: शोषयत्येव पातालं विवान्गन्धवहः शुचिः । ह्रदांश्च सरितश्चैव सागरांश्च तथैव ह ॥
data.md: That sacred carrier of perfumes, blowing at his pleasure dries up rivers, lakes and seas, including the very nether region.

data.v: त्वां संरक्षेत पवनः सखित्वेन न संशयः । तस्माद्बहलशाखोऽसि पर्णवान्पुष्पवानपि ॥
data.md: Forsooth, Pavana protects you out of friendship. It is, therefore, that, though possessed of numberless branches, you have still leaves and flowers.

data.v: इदं च रमणीयं ते प्रतिभाति वनस्पते । यदिमे विहगास्तात रमन्ते मुदितास्त्वयि ॥
data.md: O king of the forest, this your hue is delightful since these birds, O child, filled with joy, sport on your twigs and branches.

data.v: एषां पृथक्समस्तानां श्रूयते मधुरः स्वरः । पुष्पसंमोदने काले वाशतां सुमनोहरम् ॥
data.md: When you put forth your blossoms, the sweet notes of all these dwellers of your branches are heard separately when they sing their melodious songs.

data.v: तथेमे मुदिता नागाः स्वयूथकुलशोभिनः । घर्मार्तास्त्वां समासाद्य सुखं विन्दन्ति शल्मले ॥
data.md: Again, O Shalmali, these most beautiful elephants, bathed in sweat and indulging in cries (of joy), approach you and enjoy happiness here.

data.v: तथैव मृगजातीभिरन्याभिरुपशोभसे । तथा सार्थाधिवासैश्च शोभसे मेरुवद्द्रुम ॥
data.md: Similarly various other animals living in the woods, also adorn you. Indeed, O tree, you appear beautiful even like the mountains of Meru, peopled by all creatures.

data.v: ब्राह्मणैश्च तपःसिद्धैस्तापसैः श्रमणैरपि । त्रिविष्टपसमं मन्ये तवायतनमेव ह ॥
data.md: Resorted to also by Brahmanas endued with ascetic success, by others engaged in penances, and by Yatis devoted to meditation this your region, I think, is like the celestial region itself.

data.v: बन्धुत्वादथ वा सख्याच्छल्मले नात्र संशयः । पालयत्येव सततं भीमः सर्वत्रगोऽनिलः ॥
data.md: Narada said Forsooth, O Shalmali, the dreadful and irresistible god of wind always protects you friendliness.

data.v: न्यग्भावं परमं वायोः शल्मले त्वमुपागतः । तवाहमस्मीति सदा येन रक्षति मारुतः ॥
data.md: It seems, O Shalmali, that a close intimacy exists between you and the Wind. It seems, you have said him these words, viz.,-I. am yours-and it is, therefore, that the Wind-god protects you.

data.v: न तं पश्याम्यहं वृक्षं पर्वतं वापि तं दृढम् । यो न वायुबलाद्भग्नः पृथिव्यामिति मे मतिः ॥
data.md: I do not see the tree or mountain or palace in this world which may not, I think, be broken by the Wind.

data.v: त्वं पुनः कारणैर्नूनं शल्मले रक्ष्यसे सदा । वायुना सपरीवारस्तेन तिष्ठस्यसंशयम् ॥
data.md: Forsooth, you stand here with all your branches and twigs and leaves, simply because, O Shalmali, you are protected by the Wind for some reason or reasons (unknown to us)!

data.v: न मे वायुः सखा ब्रह्मन्न बन्धुर्न च मे सुहृत् । परमेष्ठी तथा नैव येन रक्षति मानिलः ॥
data.md: The Wind, O twice-born one, is either my friend nor companion nor well-wisher. Nor is he iny great Creator that he should protect me.

data.v: मम तेजोबलं वायोर्भीममपि हि नारद । कलामष्टादशीं प्राणैर्न मे प्राप्नोति मारुतः ॥
data.md: My terrific energy and power, O Narada, are the greater than the Wind's. In sooth, the strength of the Wind is only an eighteenth part of mine.

data.v: आगच्छन्परमो वायुर्मया विष्टम्भितो बलात् । रुजन्द्रुमान्पर्वतांश्च यच्चान्यदपि किंचन ॥
data.md: When the Wind blows fearfully, tearing up trees and mountains and other things, I abate his strength by displaying mine.

data.v: स मया बहुशो भग्नः प्रभञ्जन्वै प्रभञ्जनः । तस्मान्न बिभ्ये देवर्षे क्रुद्धादपि समीरणात् ॥
data.md: Indeed, the Wind that breaks many things has himself been again and agair broken by me. Therefore, O celestial Rishi, I am not afraid of him even when he comes in fury.

data.v: शल्मले विपरीतं ते दर्शनं नात्र संशयः । न हि वायोर्बलेनास्ति भूतं तुल्यबलं क्वचित् ॥
data.md: Narada said-O Shalmali, what you think seems to be quite the reverse of truth. There is no doubt in this. There is no created thing which is so strong as the Wind.

data.v: इन्द्रो यमो वैश्रवणो वरुणश्च जलेश्वरः । न तेऽपि तुल्या मरुतः किं पुनस्त्वं वनस्पते ॥
data.md: Even Indra, Yama, Vaishravana, of Varuna the king of the waters, is not equal to the god of wind in might. What to speak of you who are only a tree.

data.v: यद्धि किंचिदिह प्राणि शल्मले चेष्टते भुवि । सर्वत्र भगवान्वायुश्चेष्टाप्राणकरः प्रभुः ॥
data.md: The illustrious Wind-god is always the root of all the acts of creatures in this world, since it is he that is the giver of life.

data.v: एष चेष्टयते सम्यक्प्राणिनः सम्यगायतः । असम्यगायतो भूयश्चेष्टते विकृतो नृषु ॥
data.md: When the god does his work properly, he makes all living creatures live at their ease. When, however, he does it improperly, calamities visit the Earth.

data.v: स त्वमेवंविधं वायुं सर्वसत्त्वभृतां वरम् । न पूजयसि पूज्यं तं किमन्यद्बुद्धिलाघवात् ॥
data.md: What else can it be but weakness of understanding which induces you not to adore the god of wind, that foremost of beings in the universe, and worthy of adoration.

data.v: असारश्चासि दुर्बुद्धे केवलं बहु भाषसे । क्रोधादिभिरवच्छन्नो मिथ्या वदसि शल्मले ॥
data.md: You are worthless and of a wicked understanding, you are but making an idleboast. Your intelligence being confounded by anger and other passions, you indulge in untruths, O Shalmali.

data.v: मम रोषः समुत्पन्नस्त्वय्येवं संप्रभाषति । ब्रवीम्येष स्वयं वायोस्तव दुर्भाषितं बहु ॥
data.md: I am certainly angry with you, for your giving vent to such words. I shall myself communicate to the Windgod all these derogatory words of yours.

data.v: चन्दनैः स्पन्दनैः शालैः सरलैर्देवदारुभिः । वेतसैर्बन्धनैश्चापि ये चान्ये बलवत्तराः ॥
data.md: Chandanas, Syandanas, Shalas, Saralas, Devadarus, Vetasas and Dhanvanas and other noble trees that are far stronger than you, have never, you of wicked understanding, spoken such evil words against the Wind.

data.v: तैश्चापि नैवं दुर्बुद्धे क्षिप्तो वायुः कृतात्मभिः । ते हि जानन्ति वायोश्च बलमात्मन एव च ॥
data.md: All of them are cognisant of the power of the Wind as also the power that each of them possesses. For these reasons those foremost of trees respectfully salute that god.

data.v: तस्मात्ते वै नमस्यन्ति श्वसनं द्रुमसत्तमाः । त्वं तु मोहान्न जानीषे वायोर्बलमनन्तकम् ॥
एवमुक्त्वा तु राजेन्द्र शल्मलिं ब्रह्मवित्तमः । नारदः पवने सर्वं शल्मलेर्वाक्यमब्रवीत् ॥
data.md: Bhishma said-Having said these words to the Shalmali, that foremost of all persons conversant with Brahma, viz., Narada, communicated to the Wind-god all that the Shalmali had said about him.

data.v: हिमवत्पृष्ठजः कश्चिच्छल्मलिः परिवारवान् । बृहन्मूलो बृहच्छाखः स त्वां वायोऽवमन्यते ॥
data.md: Narada said There is a a certain Shalmali on the Himalaya, adorned with branches and leaves. His roots have gone deep into the Earth and its branches have spread wide around. That tree, O Wind-god, disrespects you.

data.v: बहून्याक्षेपयुक्तानि त्वामाह वचनानि सः । न युक्तानि मया वायो तानि वक्तुं त्वयि प्रभो ॥
data.md: He spoke many insulting words against yourself. It is not meet, O Wind, that I should repeat them in your hearing.

data.v: जानामि त्वामहं वायो सर्वप्राणभृतां वरम् । वरिष्ठं च गरिष्ठं च क्रोधे वैवस्वतं यथा ॥
data.md: I know, O Wind, that you are greatest of all created things. I know too that you are a very superior and very powerful being, and that in anger you resemble the Destroyer himself.

data.v: एवं तु वचनं श्रुत्वा नारदस्य समीरणः । शल्मलिं तमुपागम्य क्रुद्धो वचनमब्रवीत् ॥
data.md: Hearing these words of Narada, the Windgod going to that Shalmali, said to him angrily as follows.

data.v: शल्मले नारदे यत्तत्त्वयोक्तं मद्विगर्हणम् । अहं वायुः प्रभावं ते दर्शयाम्यात्मनो बलम् ॥
data.md: The Wind-god said O Shalmali, you have uttered derogatory words against me before Narada, know that I am the God of wind. I shall certainly show you my power and might.

data.v: नाहं त्वा नाभिजानामि विदितश्चासि मे द्रुम । पितामहः प्रजासर्गे त्वयि विश्रान्तवान्प्रभुः ॥
data.md: I know you well. You are no stranger to me. While creating the world, the powerful Grandfather had for a time rested under you.

data.v: तस्य विश्रमणादेव प्रसादो यः कृतस्तव । रक्ष्यसे तेन दुर्बुद्धे नात्मवीर्याद्द्रुमाधम ॥
data.md: For this incident I have hitherto shown you favour. O worst of trees, it is for this that you stand uninjured and not for your own power. You consider me lightly as if I were a vulgar thing. I shall, however, appear to you in such a way that you may not disrespect me again.

data.v: यन्मा त्वमवजानीषे यथान्यं प्राकृतं तथा । दर्शयाम्येष आत्मानं यथा मामवभोत्स्यसे ॥
एवमुक्तस्ततः प्राह शल्मलिः प्रहसन्निव । पवन त्वं वने क्रुद्धो दर्शयात्मानमात्मना ॥
data.md: Thus addressed, the Shalmali laughed in contempt and replied, saying,-O Wind-god, you are angry with me. Do not stop showing the extent of your power.

data.v: मयि वै त्यज्यतां क्रोधः किं मे क्रुद्धः करिष्यसि । न ते बिभेमि पवन यद्यपि त्वं स्वयंप्रभुः ॥
data.md: Do you vomit all your anger upon me. By becoming angry, what will you do to me? Even if your power had been all your own, I would not still have been afraid of you. I am superior to you in power. I am not afraid of you.

data.v: इत्येवमुक्तः पवनः श्व इत्येवाब्रवीद्वचः । दर्शयिष्यामि ते तेजस्ततो रात्रिरुपागमत् ॥
अथ निश्चित्य मनसा शल्मलिर्वातकारितम् । पश्यमानस्तदात्मानमसमं मातरिश्वनः ॥
नारदे यन्मया प्रोक्तं पवनं प्रति तन्मृषा । असमर्थो ह्यहं वायोर्बलेन बलवान्हि सः ॥
मारुतो बलवान्नित्यं यथैनं नारदोऽब्रवीत् । अहं हि दुर्बलोऽन्येभ्यो वृक्षेभ्यो नात्र संशयः ॥
किं तु बुद्ध्या समो नास्ति मम कश्चिद्वनस्पतिः । तदहं बुद्धिमास्थाय भयं मोक्ष्ये समीरणात् ॥
यदि तां बुद्धिमास्थाय चरेयुः पर्णिनो वने । अरिष्टाः स्युः सदा क्रुद्धात्पवनान्नात्र संशयः ॥
तेऽत्र बाला न जानन्ति यथा नैनान्समीरणः । समीरयेत संक्रुद्धो यथा जानाम्यहं तथा ॥
data.md: All of them, however, are shorn of understanding, and, therefore, they do not know, as I know, why or how the Wind succeeds in shaking and tearing them up.

data.v: ततो निश्चित्य मनसा शल्मलिः क्षुभितस्तदा । शाखाः स्कन्धान्प्रशाखाश्च स्वयमेव व्यशातयत् ॥
data.md: Bhishma said Having thus deterinined, the Shalmali, himself sorrowfully caused all his branches, man and minor, to be cut off.

data.v: स परित्यज्य शाखाश्च पत्राणि कुसुमानि च । प्रभाते वायुमायान्तं प्रत्यैक्षत वनस्पतिः ॥
data.md: Casting off his branches, leaves and flowers, in the morning the tree looked firmly at the Wind as he came towards him.

data.v: ततः क्रुद्धः श्वसन्वायुः पातयन्वै महाद्रुमान् । आजगामाथ तं देशं स्थितो यत्र स शल्मलिः ॥
data.md: Filled with anger and breathing hard, the Wind came, felling large trees, where the Shalmali stood.
